TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 245, standing in my name, be taken as a formal motion.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there any objection to 245 being taken as formal? There is an objection.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—This is not what was indicated at the whips meeting last night. It was indicated that it would be formal.
—I understand from the Manager of Government Business that there was no objection last night to it being taken as formal. Is that correct?

—by leave—Mr Acting Deputy President, I just indicate that the opposition will be opposing formality. I understood Senator Margetts was going to seek to suspend and have that motion debated. Just in terms of the opposition's position, we will not be supporting her motion.
—You can allow it to be declared formal and still oppose it. That would be a more sensible course of action.
—When you asked me to call, I called.
—No, I asked whether anybody objected to it being called formal.
—I did.
—Well you shouldn't have. You should have let it be called formal and then voted against it.

—With due respect, Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not have to call according to your instructions. In putting the motion, you asked whether anyone opposed it being declared formal and I said, `Yes, we oppose it being declared formal.' I do not need my decisions reviewed by you, with all due respect.
—Those were the arrangements that I was told were made. If it is declared formal then it can be debated.
—No, I think you heard the deputy manager of government business indicate that that was the government's position and I indicated the opposition's position.
—Then the motion is not declared formal.
—Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

BREAK.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 245.

As far as I was aware, the Australian Labor Party was going to support this motion. It is only now that I have discovered that Labor are not supporting it. The government indicated that they would support the motion being declared formal but would vote against the motion. This is the first time I have heard that Labor are not supporting the motion. So it is unfortunate that the indications now being given are different to those given in the whips' meeting.

The urgency today of the motion is Australia's international reputation involving general maritime safety in the transportation of live sheep—an issue the general community feel should be addressed urgently. The world would not fall apart if this motion were agreed to.

The motion states that there was to be a march to coincide with a London based protest by the group Compassion in World Farming and a statement regarding the number of sheep annually exported. There was nothing particularly controversial about the second call for action involving an investigation. This matter is urgent because we cannot allow these kinds of incidents to continue. There is nothing terribly controversial in these issues.

I am merely disappointed about the way things have happened today. I understood that there would be objection to the motion being declared formal, but I also understood that the Senate would support the motion. Unfortunately, Labor have sent me mixed signals in this regard. However, in a last ditch attempt to have the motion agreed to, I would ask the Senate to support this motion.

The world will not end if we find out why this incident involving the Uniceb happened. The world will not end if we instigate measures to try to prevent such an incident happening again involving large numbers of sheep and personnel in such marine disasters of ships sinking in and around Australia or anywhere else. I think it is urgent that we deal with this issue.

I would like to think that the decisions made during the whips' meetings are not reversed at the last minute. It may be that I have a mistaken belief concerning the agreements reached. This matter was raised several days ago and I was under the impression that we had been given assurances by Labor that there were no problems with this motion.

As I said, the world will not fall apart if it is supported. It is not an anti‐farmers move. It is not an anti‐agriculture move. It is aimed at ensuring that Australia's reputation is what it should be. That is why it is urgent that the motion get support in the Senate to ensure that a reasonable attitude is adopted both now and in the future on this issue. So I urge the Senate to support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this motion because I was also under the impression that there would be support for it without it being put to a debate; but we are now having a debate about the urgency of the matter. And it is a matter of very great importance. As Senator Margetts said, over 1,000 people protested a week ago in Perth about the sinking of the Uniceb carrying over 67,000 sheep to the Middle East.

SPEECH.PARA: We do not know the circumstances of that shipping disaster as very scant detail is available. It is presumed that many of the sheep were burnt. Whatever happened, they all went to the bottom of the ocean with the ship. There is a real question mark hanging over the measures to ameliorate conditions on the ship for those sheep. If I recollect correctly, unlike New Zealand, we do not have rules in place to ensure surveillance by professional veterinary officers over the conditions of the animals aboard these ships. Whatever the case, even without this disaster, we know that some 50,000 to 100,000 live sheep die in transit on the oceans out of this country every year, and that is a matter of very serious concern. An inquiry into this disaster could do nothing but good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: the question before the chair is one of urgency. Senator Brown is now debating the substance of the motion that Senator Margetts is seeking to declare formal. I ask you to either draw him back to the matter of urgency or ask him to sit down.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on the point of order: I was listening carefully to what Senator Brown said. I must say there have been a number of rulings of late which I think are very sensible, allowing senators speaking to motions for the suspension of standing orders a certain degree of flexibility. I would ask you, as you consider your ruling on this matter, to take into account some recent rulings made by those presiding in this place.

INTERJECT.PARA: I can recall even over the last sitting fortnight occasions when a certain flexibility has been determined by the President or Acting Deputy President in allowing debate in this chamber to flow as effectively as possible. This is something about which there is an enormous amount of consistency in rulings. I think it places you in a difficult position other than to call Senator Brown to debate the substance of the motion before the chair.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: MACDONALD

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I am not sure whether Senator Faulkner is talking in code for some arrangement that might have been made in relation to this matter, but as a general principle I think what Senator Faulkner says is quite wrong. If you allow substantive debate on this motion it will all be repeated again when the substantive motion is debated.

INTERJECT.PARA: There may be some arrangement in this instance that I do not know about. What happens so often is that the substantive matters are debated at this stage and then repeated in the debate on the substantive motion. Senator Brown had the temerity less than 10 minutes ago to complain about sitting for an extra two weeks. If we keep allowing him to debate the substantive matter on the motion for suspension and then repeating this during the debate on the substantive motion, we will need another two sitting weeks for the chamber. I urge you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to apply the rules as they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was going to make a decision before I had the advice of those on both sides of the House. I must say I believe the reason that a five‐minute limit was put on speeches during the debate on the motion for the suspension of standing orders was for the very reason that has been raised this morning—that is, to allow a little latitude to the person who is moving for the suspension of standing orders. Whilst I take Senator Ferguson's point, I will allow Senator Brown to continue.

—A very fine ruling, Mr Acting Deputy President. The matter is urgent. The response on the streets of Perth shows that it is urgent. Senator Margetts was under the impression, and I think fairly so, that there would not be a debate, that there would be a vote on this matter. But the Senate has determined that there will be this debate. She would have taken the shorter course. I might add that she expected that the government would come back with an alternative form of words if it was not happy with these, but that did not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: The senator will be seeking an inquiry into the matter because it is a very important one, and she may have to do that by an alternative method a little later in the day. I reiterate: it is a very urgent topic, not because we ordain it so, but because a ship has just sunk in the ocean while carrying 67,000 live sheep. This opportunity should not be lost to establish a full ranging inquiry to avoid such incidents in the future and to better settle our conscience regarding the way in which millions of animals are treated on their way to ports out of Australia in the years ahead.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Democrats want to support both the motion for the suspension of standing orders and the substantive motion. Some days ago, I was very cooperative with the government in not pulling some bills out of the non‐controversial lunchtime debate on this very issue because the minister gave me some assurances. But it seems that assurances do not matter very much if you have got the numbers to beat people into submission.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: MACDONALD

TALK.START.PARA: —Your party would know all about that.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Ferguson interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have time to listen to your interjections or I would respond to them. I place on the record the Democrats' very real concern about the sinking of this ship. I know the government has done some things and I acknowledge that, but I believe this is a unique opportunity to look again—
—What about unemployment? Are you concerned about that?
—Yes, that is the problem, Senator Macdonald. Unemployment is the issue—10,000 meatworkers put out of work by the live sheep trade. Unemployment is very much an issue.
—You are absolutely and utterly talking rubbish.
—I am not. They are the figures that are on the record.
—Order! Senator Woodley, address your remarks through the chair and keep in mind the motion that is before the chamber.
—He would not know what it is.
—Order, Senator O'Chee!

—Certainly, Mr Acting Deputy President. The problem is that it appears the government does not want to look into a very serious issue that many people in Australia are concerned about. It was given the opportunity to do something about it but it is dodging the issue. The Democrats want to put on the record their concerns about the sinking of this ship, about the cruelty to animals. If the government wants our support for this trade to continue, certainly it ought to look into issues that are raised in a serious way in this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is important for all senators to understand the reason why the opposition will be supporting the motion for the suspension of standing orders for a debate to take place on this issue, but not supporting the substantive motion. In fact, we will be supporting the opposition to this motion by the government. But it is important, particularly as recent events have indicated, that the position of the opposition on this issue not be misconstrued. I am not suggesting that Senator Brown would be crass enough to do this, but I thought there was some danger, when we do support the government on this issue, as we will, that a press statement might be issued saying that the opposition has got absolutely no concern about animal welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: It did cross my mind that that would be the result if there were nothing said in a formal debate. Perhaps I am a little more generous than I should be: there was some real chance of that happening. I did not want that to happen, because it is an important matter.

The Australian live sheep trade is a vitally important trade for Australia. It is absolutely crucial that it be conducted in the most scrupulously careful way that it can be and that the welfare of the animals involved on such journeys be protected to the maximum extent that it can be protected. In the absence of a debate—I carefully considered this this morning—I did not want to run the risk of having a deliberate misconstruction placed on that with statements then issued, as they probably would have been, saying that the federal opposition did not care about the welfare of sheep or, indeed, other animals that are conducted with these trades.

I will not speak more than is necessary in the debate proper, but I will certainly speak for long enough to put on the record the reasons why we are supporting the government on this issue and not the Greens.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion No. 245 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:
(i) on Sunday, 13 October 1996, Western Australians will march in a public display of opposition to the live sheep trade organised by People Against Cruelty in Animal Transport,

(ii) the Western Australian protest will coincide with a London‐based protest by Compassion in World Farming at the Australian High Commission in which a wreath will be laid for the 67 488 sheep which burned to death or drowned in August 1996 with the sinking of the livestock transport ship, the Uniceb , and
(iii) over 5 million live sheep are exported annually from Australia to the Middle East, and each year more than 100 000 of those die from heat stroke, disease or starvation during the journey; and
(b) calls on the Government to:

(i) instigate an investigation into the sinking of the Uniceb and the deaths of 67 488 sheep, including an investigation of the standards of the ship and inspection services, the presence of veterinarian, and safety and rescue services and procedures, and
(ii) implement measures to prevent a similar disaster happening again.

I am not going to delay the chamber for any longer than is necessary. This issue obviously concerns a great many people in the community. It is one of those issues where people who see you walking along the street or people you meet who know you are a Green will ask you, `What are you doing about the live sheep trade?' There is a lot of concern about it. It is not an anti‐employment issue. As Senator Woodley has indicated, there is an issue of value adding in Australia.

The latest thing I heard on the media the other day was that, although it is obvious that sheep can be killed in an approved manner in Australia with proper ceremonies, there is preference for freshness. One might say that that is a preference, and it is a market preference, but there are perhaps other good reasons why Australian value adding ought to be looked at in a different way. Why is Australian killed meat not considered acceptable? Perhaps we ought to look at that issue.

There are many issues here. Calling on the government to investigate sinking would not seem to me to be such an odd thing to do. If there has been an investigation into the sinking, perhaps the government could alleviate our concerns and present to us the outcome of that investigation. If an aircraft, a passenger ship or a ferry went down with a loss of lives, there would obviously be an investigation. So instigating an investigation or providing a report to the Senate as to what happened and why does not actually seem to me to be an unreasonable thing to do.

What about implementing measures to prevent a similar disaster from occurring again? It could be a case of, `Oh, well, these things happen; we have done the best we can.' But if it could be suggested that the standard of the ship was such that it was an accident waiting to happen, it is something for all of us to be concerned about.

We have had debates in this House on the Ships of shame report and what we ought to be doing and what standards are reached. If standards are not being reached and if one of the outcomes is that the live sheep trade is a result of part of this kind of shameful shipping standard system, maybe in crews, in standards, or in the safety of the ships, then perhaps it is something we ought to be talking about, instead of pretending it is not happening or that it is simply an issue of protecting the agricultural industry.

I have stood up here on many occasions talking about appropriate regional development and what we can be doing to meet the employment and other needs in regional areas. I am certainly in favour of making sure that regions do remain viable and have the means to remain viable. However, I do not think we are protecting anybody if we refuse to look at these issues. If we assume that everything that can possibly be done is being done, I do not think we are being serious about this. So if asking a simple question to get a report on an incident is considered to be outlandish, perhaps in the future we might ask for a review, which will obviously take more time. However, parliamentary inquiries—especially Senate inquiries—are very cost effective. Perhaps we could look at that option. For the government to suggest that what we are asking for is unreasonable is a bit difficult, considering that during the debate, I said to the government, `Come back to us with a form of wording. Say what you think is reasonable and we will listen to it.' But we have heard nothing.

We have had this kind of response today: `The problem does not exist. Everything is terrific. There is no problem with the safety of ships carrying sheep. There is no problem with the amount of deaths occurring. There is no problem with the way sheep are carried.' That is putting your head in the sand. It is time to start looking at these issues more carefully and to at least start admitting that there is a responsibility for governments to keep up their international reputation on these issues. Therefore I would seek support on the substantive motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill, Sen David

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government was going to agree to this motion being called formal, but to vote against the motion when it was moved. I want to just mention a couple of points that Senator Margetts has brought up about the animal welfare aspects of the trade. Yes, everyone is very concerned about animal welfare, wherever they happen to be. It was the previous government that established the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare. That committee is still in operation and will continue to be in operation. So that looks after those aspects of animal welfare.

SPEECH.PARA: In relation to the other point Senator Margetts mentioned about there being no consultation, we contacted her office about this to ask Senator Margetts to either agree to defer the motion or try to find an agreed version of the motion. But, as far as the motion is concerned, I do not believe that would be possible to do with her.

I would just make a couple of statements about the motion. The Uniceb is a live sheep vessel that sunk in the Indian Ocean at the end of August. The ship was carrying 67,500 sheep, destined for Aqaba in Jordan. The Uniceb had passed an Australian safety inspection and was inspected for animal welfare conditions immediately before its last voyage.

The Uniceb was registered in Panama and owned by an Italian group. Under the International Convention for the Safety of Ships at Sea, the authority and responsibility for undertaking investigations into the sinking of vessels lies with the country of the flag registry. Australia has no rights under the international convention either to participate in that investigation or, if we were to initiate our own investigation, to require the cooperation of the flag registry, the underwriters or the owners.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Anderson, has undertaken that, should the report of the Panamanian investigation point to any failures on the part of the Australian shippers or any others, the matter will be thoroughly investigated and appropriate action taken. The minister has met with both the RSPCA and the Australian and New Zealand Federation of Animal Societies to discuss the incident and also ways and means of improving animal welfare conditions on livestock export vessels. Both the RSPCA and ANZFAS have agreed to work with the minister in addressing issues of concern. Both groups have prepared submissions which are under consideration.

No-one could be unmoved by the suffering involved in the death of the ship's engineer, as well as so many thousands of animals. Nonetheless, we do not believe it is a productive use of the Senate's time to debate the motion which we are now debating. I seek leave to have two documents incorporated in Hansard. One is about the live sheep trade and the other gives full details of the Uniceb incident. I think they have been incorporated in Hansard during another debate in this place.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—
LIVE SHEEP CARRIER `UNICEB'—INDIAN OCEAN INCIDENT

A fire broke out on Saturday 31 August in the engine room of the Italian owned (Sistren Services), Panama flagged, live sheep vessel `Uniceb' which is chartered to exporters Wellards. The vessel left Fremantle on 23 August carrying 67,500 sheep bound for the Red Sea port of Aqaba in Jordan.

Most reports indicate that the fire broke out on either Saturday 31 August or Sunday 1 September, but this is yet to be verified. It is most likely the ship was 900‐1000 miles north‐east of Seychelles when the fire broke out.
It appears the fire commenced in the engine room and spread rapidly to accommodation areas above causing the crew to abandon ship. The ship's engineer was lost overboard during this time.

The crew later reboarded the ship and endeavoured to fight the fire, but were driven off by heat and smoke. They then drifted in life rafts for 20 hours or more until picked up by a passing ship the `Mineral Century' on Monday 2 September. (This vessel arrived in Suez on Tuesday 10 September.)

We are not aware of any radio, phone or beacon contact during the fire. Upon hearing of the fire by radio from the rescue vessel on the Monday, the Italian owners dispatched on Tuesday a fire fighting tug from Djibouti to the vessel in salvage/rescue attempt. The owners also on Tuesday diverted the `Cormo Express' to the scene. This vessel had just completed unloading sheep in Karachi.

Both the salvage tug and the `Cormo Express' arrived at the point of last sighting on Friday 6 September. A US military aircraft also participated in the search on either the Friday afternoon or Saturday covering approximately 200 sq miles.

On the Tuesday 10 September reports confirmed that debris consistent with the sinking of the `Uniceb' had been sighted floating in the vicinity and it was concluded that the ship had sunk. The search mission was then called off.

The ship's charterers, Wellard Rural Exports, believed the ship sank soon after the fire began. This is based on the fact that two explosions were heard by the crew drifting in lifeboats after they were forced to abandon the ship and that, in the period between the ship being abandoned and the sighting of the debris, there were no reports of a ship on fire in a major shipping lane into Suez and the Middle East.

Under the International Convention of Safety of Life at Sea, the flag registry, in this case Panama, is required to undertake an inquiry. This is now being conducted by the Panama representative in Bombay and is expected to take some months. The Australian Maritime Safety Authority has contacted the Panamanian authorities noting the implications for Australia and requesting a copy of the report of the inquiry into the incident. Further action by Australian authorities will be decided in the light of the report of the Panamanian inquiry.

As reported in the Sydney Morning Herald (6/9/96), the Maritime Union of Australia alleged that the Uniceb had left port hurriedly before the Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) could investigate International Transport Workers' Federation concerns about conditions for the crew and stock on board.

AMSA has confirmed that allegations were made about unsatisfactory conditions on the vessel. These related to operation of the crew accommodation air conditioning system, incorrectly flushing toilets and suspect drinking water quality. AMSA has confirmed it investigated the claims and in relation to the toilets and drinking water found them to be without substance. AMSA also was satisfied with the outcome of discussions with the ship's engineer regarding air conditioning in the crew's accommodation. AMSA reported there were no problems with the animal accommodation and that the ship had passed inspection in accordance with the Memorandum of Understanding on Port State Control and the Marine Orders. The `Uniceb' had a track record as a good, reliable vessel meeting all AMSA standards.
THE TRADE

The trade to the Middle East began in the 1960s and, with the advent of larger and more technically advanced vessels, expanded rapidly to meet strong growth in demand in the region for freshly killed meat.

1. Last year Australia exported some 5.5 million sheep worth around $207 million. Figures to end June 1996 are currently running at the same levels as last year. The Middle East is the primary destination for shipments (99%) with the UAE and Jordan the single largest importing countries.

2. There are currently 25 licensed livestock exporters and 63 importers in 29 countries of Australian sheep. The majority of animals used in the trade are sourced from producers in WA, SA, VIC, and southern NSW.

3. While there was an increase in the carcass trade following the halting of live exports to Saudi Arabia in 1991, it should be noted that there was a corresponding significant increase in live exports to neighbouring countries in subsequent years.

4. The AMLC estimates that, at a minimum, 800,000 Australian live sheep are exported each year to other Middle Eastern countries, particularly UAE and Qatar, and then slaughtered and exported to Saudi Arabia as sheep meat. The UAE has undergone sustained growth since 1990, becoming Australia's second largest market for live sheep.
5. This points to the fact that a number of countries in the Middle East, including Saudi Arabia, retain a strong preference for freshly killed meat which can only be met by the live animal trade.

6. The AMLC maintains a regular promotional program to encourage increased consumption of chilled and frozen sheep meat. Through its overseas offices in key markets the ALMA promotes the trade through a comprehensive program of consumer and trade advertising and sales promotion backed up by a technical support service.

7. The advertising strategy focuses on newspapers and magazines portraying Australian sheep meat as high quality and produced by a professional industry. General merchandising and point‐of‐sale material is also provided to stores carrying Australian sheep meat to differentiate the product from competitors. The AMLC technical officers advise retailers and consumers on the characteristics and specifications of Australian meat and conducts butcher training programs on handling, preparation and presentation.

8. The AMLC's efforts to promote sheep meat consumption also extend to regularly contacting government officials, importers and agents to maintain Australia's reputation as a supplier of high quality and safe product and reassure them, where appropriate, of the integrity of our export certification system.

Everything has been done that can be done by the government of this country. I was also a part of the live sheep export inquiry undertaken by the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare. I believe that everything which was put in place by that inquiry has been adhered to. We are wasting a lot of time in the Senate debating something that was discussed in a previous agenda item last Thursday in this very place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that all honourable senators will accept that, on a controversial issue—like so many others—it is important that there be no ground given for any attempt to mischievously misconstrue a simple vote. In that sense, I can assure honourable senators that there is no motive whatever—this is not our motion—in wasting the time of the Senate. After a number of negotiations between Senator Brownhill and me over the past few days, we had indicated that we would support the government on this issue, and I do not want that position to be misconstrued. I did not want any ground to be given for any mischievous press releases to be put out saying that the opposition did not care about the welfare of animals involved in this trade.
—We all care.

—Indeed, Senator Brownhill. The other reason it is important to put some things on the record in this debate is that animal welfare issues are not the only issue of controversy attached to the live animal trade. Indeed, Senator Margetts herself has raised the second of those issues in the debate here this morning, and that is the important question of value adding—in other words, the benefit to Australia of having all of the processing of these animals here in this country and exporting chilled or frozen meat rather than live animals.
—That is, of course, if the customer wants that.

—Indeed. That is something again that I want to put on the record—I am sure the government would have this position as well—as an important consideration. We would want to see that happen to the maximum extent possible. For that reason, it is important that the particular trades involved be constantly examined for that value adding aspect.

BREAK.PARA: The third point that needs to be made is that we are debating this morning a motion that is about the live sheep trade but, as we all know, the debate at large is about the trade in live animals. It extends to live cattle as well, because that group of people who want to shut down this trade also want to shut down the trade in live cattle. That is a matter of public record and, of course, they are entitled to that view.

As Senator Margetts correctly referred to this morning, live cattle exports are important for regional Australia. That is why it is important for me, not simply as the shadow minister for primary industries but as a Northern Territory senator, to again put our view on this issue on the record. Some $160 million in trade might not be huge bickies for Australia in the global economic picture but it is absolutely crucial in terms of the regional economy that generates that trade. I am talking about the live cattle trade from northern Australia into principally countries such as Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines.

Over the last three or four years that trade has grown from $20 million or $30 million a year to currently $130 million or $140 million a year and it is going up. The animal welfare nature of that trade is excellent. I say that because I have personally been on board the ships and inspected the conditions under which those cattle are exported. I can say categorically from personal experience that, in welfare terms, conditions on board the ships are significantly better than the conditions in the paddocks from which a lot of these animals come. There is ample space, scrupulously clean conditions, plenty of room for each individual animal—

TALK.START.PARA: —That's cattle, not sheep.

—In response to that interjection—and, with respect, it is ingenuous—I indicate that I have already made the point, and those of us who are engaged in this debate know what I am talking about, that we are debating today the issue of live sheep. It is ingenuous in the extreme to suggest that the debate proper is only about live sheep. As you know, it is not. I have said that you are entitled to support that view. The people who want to see this trade ceased are not simply concerned about live sheep; they are concerned—and I am sorry that I have to say this again in response to the interjection—about live cattle. They also want to see that closed down.
—Horses.

—Indeed. It is important that that particularly relevant issue is also canvassed in this debate. The point about value adding which Senator Margetts made this morning also applies to the live cattle trade. The AMLC is, along with the industry itself, doing a great deal to continually improve the acceptability and market demand for our chilled and frozen mutton, lamb and beef. It has been a mark of the live trade that those countries that are taking our live exports are also taking a continually increasing amount of our chilled and frozen product as the ability to buy continually improves and as the tastes of people in those countries changes.

BREAK.PARA: There are also a number of aspects of the trade—which Senator Margetts might find interesting if she is not familiar with them; and she may be—that make it very unique. Senator Margetts mentioned this morning the requirement in some of these countries for fresh meat. There is no question about that. In other words, for cultural and all sorts of other reasons there is a preference on the part of the customers to not have chilled or frozen meat. The customers may prefer meat that has been freshly prepared rather than slaughtered and dressed out weeks or even months before and chilled or frozen.It is a fact that that is changing and there is a growing demand for chilled and frozen product. This is growing at the same time as our live export trade is growing.

There is another matter that has to be raised in this regard. In some of the countries into which we are exporting live product there is a substantial lack of transport infrastructure and chiller infrastructure. In other words, the infrastructure that allows chilled and frozen product to be moved in that condition from the wharf to a central facility and then to the consumer does not exist.

I want to make the point because a lot of people even in the Northern Territory are not aware that, with respect to that live trade, other important services are provided to the rural communities in those countries to which we export the live product. A lot of people who are aware that the trade exists do not realise this happens. Cattle are exported from the port of Darwin to our near neighbours and are bought by a central agency. The cattle are then farmed out in small lots—two or three animals—to villages and individual families. It was when I saw this happening that I realised the important structural implications and why I am confident that trade has a long future ahead of it—and I note Senator Crane is nodding his head.

TALK.START.PARA: —The infrastructure is they can walk.

—Correct. Individual families look after these animals and fatten them up for six months or, in some cases, 12 months. The grandparents and children feed them from the smallholdings on which they are raised. They have an arrangement with the central supplier that allows them to participate in the profit when the animal is sold after it has been freshly slaughtered. There is a great lack of chiller infrastructure for frozen or chilled product to go overseas.

BREAK.PARA: The reason I labour this point, and it is an important point from our point of view, is that it is true that there is a lot of union concern, and quite understandable union concern.

TALK.START.PARA: —Properly so.
—I just said that, Senator.
—I'm not attacking you. I'm supporting you.

—I know you are supporting me, Senator. A very legitimate concern is that we are exporting jobs with that trade and that the animals should be slaughtered here with Australian meatworks doing it. If that was actually happening to any great degree, I would be as concerned about that as everybody else, but when you see the kind of trade we are talking about you realise there are aspects of the trade which means that this is not happening.

BREAK.PARA: The encouraging thing is—I am pleased Senator Crane supported me in this contention just a few minutes ago—that whilst we are continuing to put a live product into these markets, at the same time there is a clearly measurable increase in the amount of chilled and frozen products that are going into the same market. The Australian product generally has a reputation for quality, and the tastes of those markets are changing. People are buying Australian chilled and frozen products rather than somebody else's. The live trade helps that.

It is important to put on the record, as Senator Margetts has properly raised it, that this is not, in real terms, a market that is robbing Australia of jobs. It is a vitally important market for regional Australia. In the case of the live cattle trade from the Northern Territory, I have to say to Senator Margetts that over the last three or four years, with desperately bad drought conditions and a collapse in the price, it has been a market that has essentially saved the cattle industry in northern Australia—I might add, not only in the Northern Territory but particularly in Queensland, where many of the cattle for this live trade come from.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been pretty handy in WA too.

—Thank you, Senator Crane, for making that point. That is a fact. This trade has already grown to $160 million a year. Whilst that may not be big dollars in global Australian terms, it is very big dollars when you are talking about the impact that it is having on the regions that the trade serves.

BREAK.PARA: In conclusion, to move to what is currently happening—Senator Brownhill has canvassed this—there are an important number of things about this particular incident that need to be put on the record. There is an investigation taking place into the sinking of the Uniceb. AMSA, the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, has already indicated formally Australia's interest in this investigation and I know, from my own experience with AMSA, that that is something they will follow through.

When the report on the sinking is available and has been finalised—I have had this assurance from the minister—if there are defects or aspects that the investigation raises that are of continuing concern in an animal welfare sense or any other sense, then Australia will reserve the right to continue that investigation under its own auspices. But it is important to make the point that, because of the area where this sad event occurred, we have no rights to involve ourselves in that investigation or legally to demand the cooperation of any of the parties involved in it.

In other words, the appropriate investigation where these matters can be raised is being made now. We have formally indicated our desire to be a party to it. But we have no rights under the international maritime conventions to which we are signatories to compel, in any investigation this Senate might initiate, the cooperation of anybody. The investigation that does have those rights is under way now.

There are further—this is also important—investigations being conducted by the Bureau of Resource Sciences, which is undertaking research into the occurrence of disease among livestock exports with a view to being able to recommend to government actions that might be taken to further improve this situation. A study is currently under way in the bureau to determine what, if anything, needs to be done to improve ventilation, for example, on livestock vessels, especially to cope with the high Middle East temperatures that are experienced during the summer months. AMSA has also been asked to review the design pens and loading densities.

I want to conclude on the question of vets, which is included in the motion. It has certainly been my experience, in the investigations that have been conducted into this trade, that there are very few occasions where having veterinary surgeons on board ships would have made any material difference to the problems that commonly occur on those ships in respect of the animals. There is a requirement—I think a proper requirement—for mandating a minimum standard of experience for the people who actually look after the stock on board and there is a requirement for those people to be experienced in the handling and care of that stock.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was in our report.

—Indeed, Senator Calvert, it is in the report. There is a further protection—I think a proper one—that has been introduced in terms of the continuing attention that has been paid to the question of animal welfare, and that is that under AQIS's arrangements there is now a requirement for the clearance of stock by a qualified veterinary surgeon prior to their departure. AMSA are required to certify, from an animal welfare perspective, that the ship is in a proper condition to carry animals. A veterinary inspection and certification are required that the animals themselves are in a healthy condition prior to departure.

BREAK.PARA: This is not a toothless tiger. It is important to make the point that any stock found by AQIS that do not comply with this condition can lead to the prosecution of both the veterinarian concerned and the shipper of the animals if there has been a failure to carry out this vitally important animal welfare matter prior to inspection.

The reason I make these points is to prove that Australia has nothing at all to fear or to be concerned about in respect of the strictness with which these trades are supervised. Everyone acknowledges that there can be further improvements with these trades. I might add in respect of the Northern Territory that there has been a dramatic improvement in the standard of the vessels that are being used now to carry cattle to the point where in animal welfare terms they represent five star accommodation. I have seen that myself with forced draft ventilation and high quality food for the animals carried on board and so on. It is a very high standard indeed. The Bureau of Animal Resource Sciences is continuing to carry out research as to how the situation can be further improved.

I do not see the value in another investigation being mounted here in Australia, when we are already party to the investigation that is being conducted and that has legal standing—which any investigation we mounted at this point would not have. If there are any deficiencies found with that report when it is finally produced it is open to us to take further action at that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read most of what Senator Collins has given us in a briefing that was sent to my office. But that does not reassure me. I must say to Senator Collins that I acknowledge that there are many improvements being forced on this trade in terms of welfare but the motion calls on the government, not the Senate, to initiate an inquiry and investigate. It sounds as though the government is doing that. So I do not see any harm in that motion, and certainly no reason for the kind of reaction that it has had here this morning. The motion calls on the government, not the Senate, to implement measures to prevent a similar disaster happening again. That is a terribly reasonable proposition as far as I am concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: I personally support—and I want it on the record—the live sheep and cattle trade, but the best way to prejudice that trade is to ignore issues. I know that this debate is not ignoring the issues. However, I am surprised at the reaction to a very simple and not at all controversial proposal that, I think, would reassure people out there who are concerned, who do not have the information we have and who are very angry about what they see as cruelty to animals.

This is not necessarily a lot of wild-eyed people running down the street. The live sheep trade is opposed by the RSPCA, for example. I am not opposed to it, but I am concerned about the impression given when a very innocuous motion is put. I am not saying that in a pejorative way. I am not trying to put Senator Margetts down; I think she was trying to be helpful by moving a motion which I think should have been accepted by everybody without debate, but is not. Despite what you say about press releases, Senator Collins, we do not need press releases. People who are concerned about these issues will read the Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree. But we would have got some if we hadn't said anything.
—I do not know. They may still go. I will not have the time, but others may.
—At least I am on the record, Senator.

—Good. I want to underline that I believe that what we are doing by not passing this motion is not reassuring the people who are concerned about the cruelty which is involved from time to time in this trade. The Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare tabled a report about live sheep export 10 years ago. For the students of history, the committee was chaired by former Senator George Georges from Queensland, a friend of mine. It included my Democrat colleague from Western Australia, former Senator Jack Evans, and former National Party Senate leader Senator Scott from New South Wales. It was a very good report. The report came to this conclusion:

SPEECH.PARA: If a decision were to be made on the future of the trade purely on animal welfare grounds, there is enough evidence to stop the trade. The trade is, in many respects, inimical to good animal welfare, and it is not in the interests of the animal to be transported to the Middle East for slaughter.

The committee went on to acknowledge that the animal welfare aspects of the trade could not be divorced from economic and other considerations. I am very aware of that. The live cattle trade and the live export sheep trade has been the only thing that has kept our wool industry and our cattle industry afloat. The rest of it has been bad news, but the live animal trade has enabled them to survive. So I am aware of those economic and other considerations. The committee recommended a range of reforms aimed at alleviating at least some of the suffering of the sheep. More importantly, the committee recognised the need to develop a long term solution. It recognised that the substitution of the refrigerated sheep meat trade offers such a solution.

I have listened to Senator Collins this morning. I acknowledge that for at least part of this trade the customers do not accept frozen carcasses. I understand that. Nevertheless, one still has a question in one's mind about whether or not the frozen carcass trade has really been promoted as I think it should have been. The report said:

The Federal government should promote and encourage the expansion of the refrigerated sheepmeat trade to the Middle East and other countries, with the aim of eventually substituting it for the live sheep trade.
That was a report of 10 years ago, and I know we have moved on. But I wanted to put on the record that these concerns have been raised for a very long time.

In answer to an interjection from Senator O'Chee before: I do not know about the figures but, having had conversations with the AMIEU in Townsville and in other places and having watched the closure of meatworks in many towns in my state of Queensland, I am afraid that I take seriously what the meatworkers union tells me about the loss of jobs. I believe we are losing jobs in that industry, we are closing down meatworks, and I cannot agree that there is no connection between that and the live sheep trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —It might have something with the price.

—It has got something to do with the price, and that is the other problem, of course: once you supply one part of a market, of course you are going to get a much higher price for that product—as we do get almost double the price for live sheep as we get for sheep for slaughter. But one wonders whether or not, in reinforcing one part of the trade, you in fact degrade the other half.
—We don't have a stranglehold on the sheep market.
—I cannot hear you, Senator Collins, or I would probably respond to your interjection.
—We don't have a world dominance on the sheep market. Someone else will certainly supply them if we don't.

—Yes, I am certainly aware of that. But let me point out, Senator Collins, that the information I have contradicts what you said. So it may be that we will need to consult later on. The Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation advised my office—I hope Senator Collins is listening—that the frozen carcass trade actually declined by nearly half last financial year due to the product simply not being available during the peak supply period. That is an interesting statistic. I do not know whose information is correct; I am simply giving you what the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Corporation advised my office. We will have to compare our sources, I think, and find out what the true situation is. But that certainly would seem to indicate that priority in supply is being given to the live sheep trade over the carcass trade.

SPEECH.PARA: We have already debated the issues of value adding, and live sheep trade and live cattle trade must be the least value added industry that one could imagine. We all know the importance to primary industry of value adding.

These are the concerns the Democrats have. I believe that Senator Margetts was being responsible in raising this issue here. I know we have had the debate, but I cannot understand why the government and opposition do not agree with the very sensible recommendations that she has made. The first, to instigate an investigation, has been done, and we are happy. We hope that it proceeds and we will look for the report. The second recommendation, to implement measures to prevent a similar disaster happening again, is simply asking not the Senate but the government to do that. Senator Margetts, you are to be commended for bringing this motion. Certainly, the Democrats will support you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to make some comments. I hope I will not go over the ground that has already been gone over because I know there are time constraints in this debate. I support the remarks of Senator Brownhill. I also acknowledge very strongly the accuracy of the remarks made by Senator Collins on this issue.

SPEECH.PARA: My problem with this motion—and on the surface it looks perfectly all right—is that, firstly, it cannot be implemented with any force whatsoever or with any effectiveness and, secondly, what it is actually seeking to have done is being done or has already been done. So we have a motion before us which can go nowhere and in effect do very little. There is already a commitment, if we are not satisfied with what comes out of the international inquiry, that the government will take further action on this issue. I do not know how much further you can go in a practical sense.

There are couple of matters I want to deal with on the issues that have been raised here. You cannot deal with this resolution in isolation from the total sheep industry—including the woolgrowing industry—from mutton production in this country and from what occurs when we see changes in how live sheep are received or imported into various countries.

There are realities we have to face with regard to the economics of this. And I should declare an interest here because I have been involved in the live sheep export trade as a producer now for as long as I can remember, going back to the Singapore wether days, the big thumpers—which is a long time ago indeed, when this trade first became recognised in Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're extremely old.

—I am very old when it comes to some of this, but I was very young then, so I am not so old after all. I can remember at about five years of age helping Dad load Singapore shipping wethers onto the back of a truck—or it might even have been a wagon in those days.
—Probably drawn by horses.
—Yes, it was.
—I can remember those days.

—I can too. I make the point that you cannot deal with this in isolation. I recognise that this economic argument that it costs jobs in Australia has been argued many times. But I want to refer people to the Geoff Miller report that was done in the early 1980s. I am not sure if it was at the end of the Fraser government or the beginning of the Hawke government, but that goes into the whole economic structure of what occurs in the live sheep trade.

SPEECH.PARA: The particular point is that, when the live sheep trade out of this country drops off, substitution comes in and those live sheep then go into the meatworks. The amount of mutton that was being processed through the meatworks from other sheep that were not suitable for live shipment then drops off, and the net result is that the vast majority of those sheep that were previously going through the abattoirs get shot. It is as simple as that. In practice, that is what happens. There is a direct substitution, as you go down the line, when live sheep trade drops off. That is very important. When looking at the economics of this particular trade, we must take into account the production stage, the abattoir stage, the live sheep trade stage and the production of sheep foodstuff that goes onto the ships.

I make another point while referring to these two reports—Export of live sheep from Australia, a report from the Senate Select Committee on Animal Welfare in 1985, which has already been mentioned, and the update of that in 1991. Senator Calvert and Senator Brownhill were on that committee, and I believe Senator Burns was chairman at that particular time. I have not actually checked that, but I am pretty certain that is correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Cooney over here was on it.

—Senator Cooney—good, well done. I do not believe there is any other industry in Australia that has been so thoroughly researched and worked through. One has to acknowledge that. Back in the 1970s I went on board ships and had a look at what happened then. It is a very different scenario today.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no doubt that it was very sad, very disappointing, when this ship burnt and sank. It is worth pointing out that—and I do not know what else could have been done in Australia in that circumstance—the Uniceb was subjected to an AMSA safety inspection in May 1996 and was passed as fit for operation in Australian waters. It was again inspected for animal welfare conditions prior to its loading in Fremantle, immediately before its last voyage. So, in debating this issue, we cannot say that the processes that have been put in place were not adequate. The reason I referred to the past is that there have been, are and will continue to be improvements in this particular trade.

I wish to also emphasise the point, having been on the modern ships, that the sheep go through pre‐feeding and other processes before they go on the ship—they do not go directly onto the ship—and in fact in many instances the sheep live in better conditions than they actually do out in the paddock. The improvement that has occurred there is very significant.

I want to now re‐emphasise a point Senator Bob Collins made earlier. With the development of the live sheep trade into many of these countries, the consumption of processed meats has been gradually going up and will continue to go up. That is part of the process. There may come a time when the economics will indicate that most, if not all, of the meat will be processed. I doubt whether it will ever be all because there are other issues, such as religious ceremonies and lack of transport, involved.

One of the things that is very important to the people in the Middle East is the fact that those animals can actually walk around the place. That is how they take them and utilise many of them. When we do not supply them, they come from countries north of them or from South America, potentially from South Africa or from other countries. So there is a direct substitution for the live sheep trade.

One must also acknowledge—with the sadness of this particular event I mentioned—that sheep get burnt when fires get away from national parks. Do we legislate against that? I have also seen situations where floods have occurred and sheep have been drowned. It is all very sad, but these things, unfortunately, are realities of life.

I want to acknowledge and congratulate all those people who over the last 20 to 25 years have been involved in the process of gradually improving the conditions in the live sheep trade. In mentioning that, I must also include in that the road transport sector, which is a very important part of it. If we look at the trucks that carry the stock today compared to those that existed 10, 15, 20 or 25 years ago, you really do see the Rolls Royce of invention, of modification, of application. There has been an enormous improvement in the training that is given to the people who drive those trucks by the various operators.

I will conclude my remarks by re-emphasising that it is indeed an unfortunate incident that occurred. We have to work to improve the situation. I look forward to the outcome of the international report. If I am not satisfied with that report when it comes before us, I will, as I am sure other senators in this place will, proceed or endeavour to have additional work done on this issue. In the meantime, I believe it is pointless for this place to pass a motion which cannot implement anything more. In fact, it would not go as far as the action that has already been taken.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very good debate. It arises from a very useful motion by Senator Margetts, which, unfortunately, I think is about to be defeated. But it was well worth raising because it goes to the issue of how animals should be properly treated. We as a nation ought to see to that. Senator Brownhill, who began the debate for those opposing the motion, has done splendid work on the animal welfare committee. He would understand what I am saying. The debate has been about trying to see to the economy and, at the same time, see to the proper treatment of animals. They are issues that cannot be resolved at one time. I agree with the thrust of what Senator Margetts has said: this ought to be an ongoing issue.

SPEECH.PARA: We could go to plenty of people to get some material about this. Senator Woodley spoke about the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union in Queensland. Certainly that is a body to which we should pay great heed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, hardly any sheep go from Queensland.
—I was going to go on, Senator Brownhill, and talk about that union in Victoria. Live sheep were taken from Victoria.
—Correct.

—The secretary of the union in Victoria, Mr Walter Curran, is one of the most outstanding unionists that this country has been blessed with. Senator Crane would agree that Wally Curran is the sort of person who could give us a great deal of advice about this because he is a man of great compassion. Mr Acting Deputy President, I see that you agree with what I am saying now. Wally Curran not only has compassion but also has a great business sense and a great idea of how the economy should run. He is the sort of person whose advice we would look to if there were to be an inquiry—which I understand there is not at this stage.
—There has been an inquiry.
—I know. Of course there have been inquiries. In fact, the animal welfare committee—
—You were on it, Senator Cooney.

—I know. What I said before, and I think this is the point that Senator Margetts is making, is that, as with many things, you cannot come to a conclusion at one point of time and think that is the end of the matter. These things keep developing. This motion is a development. The disaster that happened to this ship certainly raises other issues.

SPEECH.PARA: All I am saying is that, whether it is in the inquiry that Senator Margetts suggests or some other inquiry, there are lots of people we could turn to out there. As an example, I mention the Victorian secretary of the Australian Meat Industry Employees Union, and perhaps as well the deputy secretary, Mr Graham Bird, who is also an outstanding figure in this area. Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, all I can say to Senator Margetts is that now is not the time for this motion. Certainly I hope she remains interested because this is a vital area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In closing the debate today, I would like to agree with Senator Cooney that this is an important and timely debate. In my opinion, it is not wasting the Senate's time to ensure that the right and proper platform is used for these important debates. Sometimes it is assumed that only the government's agenda is important. But that is not the case; the community agenda is also important.

SPEECH.PARA: I need to take up one point that I have mentioned privately to Senator Brownhill. Senator Brownhill gave an indication, presumably from a briefing note that he has, that the Greens did not take up an offer to change the wording of the motion or to defer it. We did defer the motion; in fact we have deferred it a couple of times. I believe the briefing is out of date. So I believe it is necessary for Senator Brownhill at the first available time to correct the inference that was given because, quite late last night, the office of Senator Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy, contacted my office saying, in effect, that all bets were off and that the motion would be opposed. It is fine for the motion to be opposed, but it is simply not true that the Greens were not interested in changing the wording. We offered that to the minister. In the end, the minister said he was not interested in changing the wording. So I would like to invite Senator Brownhill to correct that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say that what you have just said is correct.
—I will allow you to do that on the Hansard ; that would be fine—through you, Mr Acting Deputy President.
—It is in Hansard now.
—Through you, Mr Acting Deputy President, I do not think an interjection in this case is adequate; I think time should be made available for a statement to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: An Australian cargo was involved. The indication is that Australia has no rights to conduct an investigation. It is true that Australia has no rights under the international convention to either participate in an investigation or to insist on access from the flag registry, the underwriters or the owners. That does not mean to say that Australia has no rights to an investigation.

It should also be noted here that the Uniceb, the ship involved, is registered in Panama. Often ships registered in Panama are considered to have flags of convenience. Panama has had many problems with its standard of shipping. On many occasions we have had debates as to the adequacy of what we in Australia can do in relation to the standard of shipping. I do not think it is sufficient—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ships of shame.

—The Ships of shame report, as Senator Woodley interjects. It is not sufficient to say that Australia can do nothing. We have had debates here about the ability of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority to undertake adequate inspections. I am on record as saying that the resources that are available to the Australian Maritime Safety Authority simply do not give it the ability to make full and adequate safety inspections. In the past we have had very damning reports from the Auditor‐General indicating similar things, that there have been problems.

BREAK.PARA: The fact that the Australian Maritime Safety Authority inspection in May 1996 passed the Uniceb as fit for operation in Australian waters needs to be taken further. Perhaps we need to know what was the nature of the inspection, how long it took, and how adequate it was. What did AMSA inspect, and what was the basis of its being able to say it was fit for operation? If it is as a result of a lack of resources that AMSA was not alerted to potential problems, or if it is something that was nothing whatever to do with adequate inspection, we are entitled to know these things. If we see what is an AMSA report, that is fine, but perhaps there needs to be some scrutiny as to whether AMSA simply has a lack of resources or whether something different is the problem.

I am pleased to see that there is some interest. A number of people have been alerted to the issue and will be watching carefully for, firstly, the outcome of the international investigation and, secondly, the AMSA response. You can be sure that we will revisit this debate when we hear that response. If it be a matter of AMSA resourcing, the Australian government has a responsibility to address the matter. If AMSA does not have proper resources—I am just surmising that—it has to be dealt with.

I also want to deal briefly with comments that Senator Bob Collins made in relation to the cattle trade. Senator Collins made an assumption which, I believe, was unwarranted. The assumption was that if I move a motion in relation to the standards of the shipping of live sheep, I am associated automatically with an attack on the live cattle export trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't say you were, Senator.
—There was an implication. The word `ingenuous' was used.
—But not in respect of your good self.

—Despite that, I make it very clear that within my support base—the Greens (WA) and the green movement in general—there is no clear‐cut deci sion on live cattle exports. There are a number of reasons for that.

BREAK.PARA: Those reasons include the fact that there is a great deal of concern about the level of overstocking and land degradation in pastoral areas of Western Australia. One way of getting cattle growers to look after their land better and not overstock it is by convincing them to produce higher value breeding stock. That is an issue which we, as well as other people in the community, are considering.

Further, there is no single opinion on the farming of native animals. There are people in the environment movement who believe that emus and kangaroos should not be considered for farming. There are other people in the environment movement who believe it is more beneficial to the environment to farm animals appropriate to our environment and climate. That debate still occurs and it is very healthy.

It is wrong to assume that there is one view in the environment movement, and it is wrong to assume that there is one view among the Greens in relation to these issues. It is right to assume that these debates should occur. The problem is suggesting that the issue is about animal exports in general. That detracts from the fact that because sheep exports are, on a unit by unit basis, a much lower value product, the pressures, understandably, are much greater on growers not to create a requirement for improved conditions.

I can understand these issues. We should not look at them and simply say that we know that standards could be considerably better for cattle exports. But that does not mean that as a community and a parliament we should not be looking at the standard of shipping, the standard of crewing and the health and humane standards of live sheep exports.
I am very pleased that this debate has occurred. I still call on the Senate to support the motion, but I can count. I look forward to the outcome of any inquiry that takes place on this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Trade and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

I said that in my interjection. I think she also needs to realise that the National Consultative Committee on Animal Welfare also does a lot for animal welfare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Electronic Technologies entitled R‐ rated material on pay TV part 2 and review of the guidelines for the classification of film and videotapes , together with the Hansard record of proceedings.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to have the tabling speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: This report is timely. It comes at a time when a major Pay TV operator is advertising a service which will consist mainly of showing R‐rated material on Pay TV. The Committee is not satisfied that the concerns which it has previously expressed on this matter have been addressed before such a service is made available on subscription or pay television.

In previous reports on this issue, the Committee indicated its belief that the Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) should complete extensive Australia‐wide qualitative and quantitative research on community standards of taste and decency in relation to classifications for pay television, and on what levels of violence and depiction of sex should be allowed. The Parliament also indicated its support for such research in the Schedule to the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 (Schedule 2, Part 6). The Committee reported to the Senate in 1995 that the ABA's research was flawed and recommended that the OFLC recast the R category. In their latest report on this matter the OFLC has undertaken some minor adjustments to R but not carried out the comprehensive recast of R required by the Community Standards Committee.
So in this report, the Committee's first major recommendation is for the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to be amended to prevent the broadcast of R‐rated and X‐rated material on pay TV.

The Committee also expresses its concern in this report at the lack of accountability in the decision‐making process adopted by the Commonwealth, State and Territory Censorship Ministers when making decisions in relation to the Classification Act and to the guidelines. The Committee believes that amendments to the National Code under section 6 of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1996 and determinations or amendments of the classification guidelines under section 12 should be disallowable instruments by the Commonwealth Parliament. It is recommending that the Classification Act be amended accordingly.

The Committee is repeating its call for a restructuring of the Office of Film and Literature Classification (OFLC). It is important that the community should perceive the OFLC to be truly reflective of community standards. One way for this to be achieved would be for the OFLC to work closely with a community committee which represents major interest groups such as parents, teachers, churches, academics, women, young people, aboriginal and ethnic groups. The Committee is recommending that such a community committee be set up and that the positions of Director and deputy Director of the Classification Board be drawn from such community representatives.

The Film and Video Guidelines were last revised in 1988 and the Committee had recommended in Part 1 of its report tabled in February 1995, that a review of those guidelines should be undertaken. The OFLC undertook such a review last year in 1995 and the revised Guidelines were gazetted in September this year. It is those guidelines that the Committee has reviewed.

The Committee recognises that the new guidelines are intended to be more strict in relation to depictions of violence and sexual violence but it is concerned that there is still a lack of precision about the criteria which is to be applied when making classification decisions. The Committee is particularly concerned to see to it that video material which enters the home environment should have lower levels of intensity in relation to depiction of violence and sexual violence. Accordingly, the Committee is recommending that separate guidelines be introduced for the classification of videotapes to ensure that higher standards are applied than for equivalent categories of film for cinema release.

Of great concern to the Committee was the fact that video material which has been given a particular classification prior to the introduction of the system of consumer advice in 1989 and those rated M prior to the introduction of the MA classification in 1993 are still available in the community under the old classifications. The Committee believes that such material should be recalled and reclassified in the light of the newly issued stricter guidelines and it has made a recommendation to that effect.

The OFLC has foreshadowed a review of the publications and computer games classification guidelines. The Committee believes that these reviews should be conducted with greater accountability and transparency and the Committee looks forward to being involved in the review process. I commend the report to the Senate.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard
Leave granted.

BREAK.PARA: Commonwealth funding for the vocational education and training sector for 1996 has already been appropriated under the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992.
This bill would provide for supplementation of the 1996 amount in line with normal price adjustments.
The bill would also assure a Commonwealth contribution of $891 million in 1997 for vocational education and training.
Although this is a reduction of the previously legislated amount, it would still provide an increase of $10.6 million over 1996 funding.

Care has been taken in identifying the savings to ensure that they have minimum impact on training opportunities. This reflects the Commonwealth's emphasis on growth in student places, particularly for young people.
Funding for 1997 includes $70 million for growth funds.

The Commonwealth expects states and territories to continue to honour their undertakings spelled out in the Australian National Training Authority (ANTA) agreement, including maintaining their own effort in the vocational education and training sector.

The bill would also appropriate funding for 1998, in accordance with the Commonwealth's undertaking in the ANTA agreement to provide triennial funding for the vocational education and training sector.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was interrupted by a move to other business last night, I was speaking on the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill and expressing considerable surprise, having sat through the same set of hearings as members of the opposition, that they could come to such radically different conclusions based on the evidence. Government senators who participated in this inquiry strongly recommended at the end of the evidence that the bill be passed in its present form.

SPEECH.PARA: We rejected the key recommendations of the opposition parties that Telstra remain in full public ownership. Importantly, in light of the motion foreshadowed this morning, we also rejected that the bill be split. We rejected that the $1 billion national heritage environment package be funded from other sources. We did this because we had expert witnesses appear before the committee. We had witnesses from the Department of Communications and the Arts who detailed the provisions of this bill and raised very convincing arguments that it would deliver world‐class consumer protection guarantees prior to the part‐privatisation.

The evidence that we were given completely demolished the opposition parties' attempts to make wild scaremongering claims about the loss of consumer protection when we move to the part‐privatisation of Telstra. They began this scare campaign during the 1996 election and they refined this further in the debate. The universal service obligation—the USO— and consumer service guarantees are firmly entrenched in the Telecommunications Act of 1992. They are not diminished or affected in any way by the passage of this bill.

Telstra's obligations to the consumers are not diluted by part‐privatisation, and whether ownership of Telstra will be 100 per cent public or one‐third privatised has no bearing at all on the government's commitment to the USO. The bill, in fact, provides new benefits to business and a guarantee of no timed local calls for business users.

The bill in no way affects the existing legislative or other protections of directory assistance, untimed local calls and the provision of public telephone call boxes across Australia. For example, the USO expenditure by Telstra in the rural electorate of Grey—which would be close to your heart, Mr Acting Deputy President Ferguson, because it is in your area and you will be heartened to know this—is $21 million and that will be retained under this legislation. Additional evidence provided to the Senate inquiry highlights how improved efficiencies in a partly privatised Telstra would flow through to the communications sector and to the wider community.

Potential gains in living standards are estimated to be $2 billion. Reductions in the price of communications services are estimated to be in the order of 12 per cent. The long run gain economy wide to the GDP will be $1.7 billion and the economy wide gain in wages is estimated to be $3 a week.

Stimulation of the development of telecommunications services and equipment industries will be another beneficial outcome of a growing and robust Telstra. Service delivery to all Australians will improve considerably, as it has in a similar exercise undertaken in New Zealand. Over there, waiting time for new phone line connections is down from six weeks to three days. That is the sort of benefit you get when you bring in some of the disciplines of the marketplace. The company actually becomes responsive to what consumers want.

There is a bonus in all this as well in that what we are proposing keeps Telstra almost totally Australian owned. At least 88.3 per cent will be off limits to foreign ownership and the maximum individual holding for any one investor in Telstra will be 1.7 per cent, accumulating to a total of 11.7 per cent for all overseas ownership.
