Let me turn finally to the enormous benefits for rural and regional Australia of the part privatisation of Telstra. As communications costs are reduced in regional Australia, new jobs will be created. One of the great things about new technology in communications is that it does not really matter where you are located if you are on the information superhighway. It gives the nation a real opportunity to decentralise industries that do not really have to be in the centre of the major cities.

The reduced communications costs and new services provided will disproportionately, we believe, benefit rural and regional Australia. The cost disadvantage of living and doing work outside metropolitan areas will come down substantially, making regions more attractive for establishing new businesses. Telephone inquiry centres for banks, company service centres, catalogue sales—these are all the sorts of things that can be located in country areas. Tele industries for airline and hotel reservations, insurance and car rental firms will also have inducements to go to rural areas, as has occurred in the United States. In places like Nebraska those sorts of industries have moved out of the big cities to rural areas because of lower costs, to the great benefit of rural employment.

Contrary to Labor's scare campaign, the part privatisation of Telstra will have positive effects on employment in the overall telecommunications sector and supplier industries. The sector is growing at 18 per cent per annum. Job cuts in Telstra will be offset by new opportunities in this sector and in the economy as a whole.

Alan Horsley from the Australian Telecommunications Users Group told the Senate inquiry that members of his industry group face a desperate shortage of qualified staff. Telstra staff are qualified and will be snapped up by new players in the communications sector. Many of these new companies will be operating and offering employment in regional Australia.

The opposition in this debate and during the Senate inquiry have peddled so‐called employment `nasties' to frighten the community. Specifically, Labor has charged that massive job reductions will occur in Telstra across regional and rural Australia. These allegations are not true. Qualified Telstra technicians will win new, interesting jobs on the payroll of new telcos and communications companies. In 1996‐97, 70 to 80 per cent of Telstra redundancies will occur in metropolitan areas, not rural areas. Tasmania, for example, will be affected by less than one per cent of the redundancies.

Failure by Telstra to become efficient and cost effective post‐1997 as a 100 per cent publicly owned company will only see Telstra lose more market share to those new, eager competitors we will be getting after the middle of next year.Employment levels and job opportunities will really be eroded if this is allowed to happen. Telstra could become like another publicly owned dinosaur—maybe like the ANL or the National Rail Corporation.

Labor, in government, oversaw a very large downsizing of employment at Telstra. In 1985, Telecom employed over 90,000 people. Under the Labor government, the Telstra work force fell to 76,000 people. That had nothing to do with part privatisation. That was driven by changes in technology. All of that downsizing, I remind the Senate, occurred under full public ownership.

Technological change and progressive digitisation of the network is the thing that drives the trend. Digitisation of networks means lower operating costs for access lines and reduced employment. After a slow start, Telstra is starting to match the overseas telcos, but it is 25 per cent off the pace. The pace needs to be accelerated. It will be accelerated with the part privatisation of Telstra.

I welcome the announcement by the Minister for Communications and the Arts (Senator Alston) on Telstra's timetable for upgrading the phone network. This development is a sign of the efficiencies that we can expect under part privatisation. Telstra will be brought up to world standard by the passage of this bill. The open communications market post‐ 1997 demands that Telstra be allowed to compete effectively with new players. To oppose this bill is not to save Telstra; rather, it will sow the seeds of Telstra's decline. I support the bill and commend its passage to the Senate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —The government's proposal to sell off Telstra is, like the workplace relations bill, another disastrous piece of legislation—a piece of legislation that will do irreparable harm to the economic and social infrastructure of Australia. I deliberately use the words `to sell off Telstra' because that is what this government has in mind. Notwithstanding that the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill currently before the Senate proposes the one‐third privatisation of Telstra, we know that the real agenda of the government is the total privatisation, the total sale of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been confirmed by Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications and the Arts, that that is the government's real agenda. Once we proceed down the path of the partial sale of Telstra, the inevitable result will be its complete sale. What we are really debating is the future of Telstra as, firstly, a fully publicly owned corporation and, secondly, as the major corporate government asset that the people of Australia have.

Telstra is the country's largest owned government asset. It is the people's greatest and most valuable corporate asset. The government has said that they have a mandate for this legislation. They seek to rely upon the fact that they put to the people at the last election that, if elected, they would proceed to sell one-third of Telstra and set up this phoney environment fund, which I will come back to later. They seek to rely upon the fact that because they won government—and I concede that; they won government significantly in terms of the number of seats they obtained in the House of Representatives—they somehow have a mandate from the people. I refute that. The results of the federal elections put the lie to that claim.

The one big issue that the people were made fully aware of at this most recent election in March 1996 was that, on the one hand, the Liberal‐National Party said that they would proceed to sell Telstra and, on the other hand, the Australian Labor Party, the Democrats and the Greens made it abundantly clear that they would not support the legislation and that they would proceed in the Senate to reject it.

The figures from the recent elections show that a majority of people, both in the House of Representatives elections and in the Senate, voted for the parties that were on the record as opposing the sale of Telstra. In the House of Representatives, 47.2 per cent of people voted for the Liberal and National parties. Some 38.8 per cent of people voted for the Australian Labor Party, 6.8 per cent of people voted for the Democrats and 2.9 per cent of people voted for the Greens. A total of 48.5 per cent of the Australian electorate in respect of the House of Representatives voted for the parties that were completely opposed to the sale of Telstra on the record and had put that policy to the people.

So a majority of people voted against this proposal, voted for the parties that were opposed to the sale of Telstra, notwithstanding the fact that the Liberal and National parties won the majority of seats. When you come to the Senate, the figures are even more conclusive. In the Senate the Liberal‐National Party's vote dropped to 43.47 per cent of the vote. The Australian Labor Party obtained 36.15 per cent. The Democrats increased, as one would have expected, to 10.82 per cent and the Greens increased to 3.17 per cent.

In the Senate vote, 50.14 per cent of the Australian electorate voted for the parties that were on the record as opposing the sale of Telstra and making very clear to the Australian people that when the legislation came before the Senate they would oppose it. That compares with only approximately 43.5 per cent of people who supported the government's proposal. So let us not have any of this nonsense that somehow the government has a mandate from the people on this issue; an issue that was widely debated and fully before the public mind when it cast its votes on March 2.

BREAK.PARA: There is no doubt that the Australian people knew that, even though they were disposed to vote to remove the Labor Party after a quite lengthy period in office—not an unnatural thing, notwithstanding my great disappointment at their decision—when this legislation and some of the other policies of this government were before the Senate they could be voted down by the Australian Labor Party and the other parties. Let me quickly turn to Telstra itself, which as I have said is the people's greatest corporate asset.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Qantas.
—I am happy to deal with Qantas later, but we are dealing with Telstra at the moment.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Tierney referred to the fact that job reductions have occurred, and that is conceded. But what the Labor Party did was corporatise Telstra and make it competitive. We have seen dramatic improvements in their position in recent years. The asset value of Telstra alone is in the vicinity of $24 billion and probably greater. The last recorded figures from 1994-95 show an annual revenue in the vicinity of $14 billion, a pre‐tax profit of $2.4 billion and an after tax profit of $1.75 billion. In 1994-95 Telstra paid a dividend to the government of some $944 million for the year. In total, Telstra was making payments to governments of around $2.7 billion.

Indeed, that performance has improved in more recent times. In the six months up to the end of 1995, the dividend paid to the government was in the vicinity of $686 million, an increase of some 66 per cent on the previous recorded figure for the relevant period. Revenue has grown by around nine per cent. Telstra has a return to equity rate of around 20.2 per cent. That is a very healthy figure. But what do we hear from the government? We hear this line that Telstra is some sort of crippled corporation that is about to fall over. Nothing could be further from the truth.

We would accept that, unlike the performance of some previous government‐run corporations or institutions, Telstra is a fantastic success. Its debt ratio has reduced to some 28 per cent and it has seen a substantial boost in its capital expenditure to around 45 per cent.

Not only is Telstra still a major employer but it is also one of the major investors in capital infrastructure in this country, particularly in information technology. Telstra is not some lumbering corporation in need of massive efficiency reform and change. It has already been through that process. Telstra is at the leading edge in telecommunications in the world; that is, in its delivery, research and development, and investment in telecommunications. All of this happens when it is 100 per cent publicly owned.

I accept that not all publicly owned companies, either in the past or today, need necessarily remain in government ownership. The previous Labor government recognised that in respect of the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas because the nature of the industry had changed so much. Qantas had about a 50 per cent share of the market and the Commonwealth Bank had around a 20 per cent share of the market. There was no point, notwithstanding the historical commitment of the Labor Party to that position. I for one regret it in many ways but I recognise the reality that the move had to be made.

That is not to say that, when you look at a corporation like Telstra that is successful, viable, efficient and at the world's leading edge in terms of service delivery, you automatically have to privatise it because you have privatised some other government institutions. That is the sort of nonsense, follow‐the‐leader argument that we get from the government when it suits them. The sort of argument we get from the government is that, because they happen to be privatising Telecom in Albania or because Fidel Castro is going to privatise his Telecom in Cuba, Australia should do the same. That is, we should sit back and say to the Australian people, `We're going to sell off Telstra. Why? Because Albania is doing it and because Cuba is doing it.' The day we have to follow the lead of Albania and Cuba is the day we should give this business away. One could argue with a far greater degree of logic—it is a minor point but it shows the stupidity of the arguments that you get from Senator Alston, the minister—that if that is what Albania and Cuba are doing, then it is a damn good reason why we should be heading in the opposite direction and retaining our Telstra in full public ownership.

As I said, Telstra is the great shining example of how a publicly owned corporation can succeed: how it can be the world's best performer; how it can demonstrate world best practice in the whole range of its operations; and, at the same time, how it can make such a great economic and social contribution to Australia's welfare. Let me turn to some of those contributions to the welfare of the Australian people that will be affected if this bill happened to, unfortunately, pass.

We know that Telstra provides substantial benefits to rural and regional Australia. Senator Panizza should recognise this more than most, given the state from which he comes. It is trite but it needs to be said: Australia is a huge continent with a very small population. It is a continent that is larger than the size of most European countries put together but with a population of only some 18 million people, compared with the hundreds of millions of people living in Europe. Equally, the same comparison can be made with the United States.

PARA.BREAK: Australia is a sparsely populated continent, as we know. Nevertheless, out of our total population of 18 million, some 6.2 million people live outside the major urban areas of the country; that is, around 37.5 per cent of Australians live outside major urban areas. We have geographic difficulties in terms of delivering basic telecommunications services, such as telephones, to all Australians—without even considering the more sophisticated services. But, because we have always believed that Australia is a fair and equitable society and that all Australians should have access to these services, we have ensured, through the combination of full public ownership and the community service obligations, that all Australians can have access to those services at an affordable price. Just like with the ABC, another fully owned public corporation, it is important to retain Telstra in full public ownership to ensure that those people will continue to have equitable treatment when it comes to the delivery of telecom munications and the various services in that industry.

BREAK.PARA: Let us look at the level of cross‐subsidisation that occurs to ensure that people in rural and regional Australia are able to avail themselves of these services. I know that some of these figures have been referred to in previous speeches, but I will just run through a few of them. In a town like Bordertown in South Australia, the cross‐subsidisation level is of the order of $1,480 and in Naracoorte the level is $1,650. If you happen to live on Kangaroo Island, the cross‐subsidisation is valued at some $2,360. If you live on Flinders Island off the coast of Tasmania, $4,930 is the current value of the cross‐subsidisation that occurs in order to ensure that these services are delivered. If you live on King Island it is $2,220. Cross‐subsidisation levels in New South Wales include $880 in Bathurst and $1,500 in Deniliquin. In Rockhampton, Queensland, it is $1,020; in Albany—back to Western Australia, Senator Panizza's home state—it is $1,780; and in Ceduna, South Australia, it is some $6,800.

These massive subsidies are available to ensure that people in outlying areas can have access to affordable telecommunications. What will be the inevitable result if you privatise Telstra? You will place at risk those levels of subsidies.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's in the bill.

—Senator Panizza says that they have some obligations in the bill with respect to community services and subsidisation. You know that in a couple of years time they will be mere words on a piece of paper. Eventually, the pressure will be on to cut costs in order to maximise profits for the shareholders whether they be Australian owned companies or foreign owned companies. In many cases, one would assume they would be foreign owned companies because of the massive size of the privatisation. The pressure will be on for the removal of those subsidies. Those subsidies will go by the board. Inevitably, there will be higher prices for telephone calls.

BREAK.PARA: Those opposite give overseas examples. I have already referred to your reliance on Albania and Cuba as examples. You only have to look at the United Kingdom and the United States and see what has happened there. Try making a phone call in those countries that are supposed to be at the leading edge of telecommunications and you will see some of the difficulties you face. Those opposite have the hide to say that our service does not measure up.

Anybody who has been on a parliamentary delegation in the last couple of years knows that one of the great things you can do when overseas is tap into Telstra's Australia direct or world direct services. The service is there because Telstra is out there promoting a successful Australian corporation. It is out there investing in Asia and other expanding markets. It is showing the world what we can provide in terms of the development of infrastructure and the delivery of telecommunications services. All we hear from those opposite is this constant undermining of its performance and its success. If you ever did try to sell it you would probably get a far less price than it is worth.

In my remaining time I want to touch on the outrageous bribe that the coalition put to the people at the last election—that is, if we can sell Telstra we can improve the environment. What an absolutely outrageous and disgraceful policy to put to the Australian people. A number of years back the Australian Labor Party took steps to protect the Australian environment in Tasmania's forests, in North Queensland, in the Great Barrier Reef and other areas. We took those steps because we believed the environment was a mainstream issue and needed to be protected.

For the Liberal and National parties to go to the people and say that the only way that this government will look towards protecting the environment, improving the environment and dealing with some of those issues is if we can sell the one great corporate asset that this country has, then that is a total abrogation of political integrity and honesty. Frankly, the people who cast their votes on the last occasion want Telstra to remain in public ownership and I am confident that the Senate will equally decide that. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Allison, Sen Lyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today as the first Democrat senator to speak in this important debate on the Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill. At the outset, I should state that we will be opposing the partial sale of Telstra. Senator Kernot led the opposition to this sale throughout the recent election campaign. No Australian will be unaware of my party's opposition to this matter. Later Senator Lees chaired the Senate inquiry into the issue—the majority report of which clearly opposes the sale. Both Senator Kernot and Senator Lees will be contributors in this debate and will once again be making the case against the part sale of Telstra.

SPEECH.PARA: The Telstra (Dilution of Public Ownership) Bill does not solely deal with the part sale, despite its title. To quote Senator Lees in today's press:
Senator Alston has crudely welded together two separate ideas within the Telstra Bill to try and force non-Government Senators to support the part sale of Telstra.

We will be seeking to break that weld. Earlier today Senator Lees gave notice of our intention to move for the division of this bill into its two constituent parts—one dealing with the part sale and one dealing with improved customer services. Regardless of whether we will be debating one bill or two tomorrow, I will be moving a series of amendments to enhance consumer protection if we reach the committee stage of the debate.

The government has attempted to bribe the Australian people by promising a world class consumer framework if one-third of Telstra is sold. We say that this is simply a way of holding the populace to ransom. The Australian Democrats will ensure that Australians are given a world case consumer framework irrespective of who owns Telstra.

We know that task will be made more difficult in a privatised environment. Although the government has promised to retain Telstra's universal service obligation, we know that it will be quite a task to ensure that it is retained, in the long run, on a privatised carrier operating in a competitive environment.

The claim repeated ad nauseam by this government that public enterprises are more inefficient than private enterprises usually overlooks one simple fact. Government enterprises are often charged with social objectives providing a measure of equity. These are, we think, just as important as profit making but are portrayed so often as sources of economic inefficiency and loss making.

While such objectives may impede the aim of profit making, their importance for furthering national goals or for promoting the national interest should not be underestimated. I acknowledge that the provision of the universal service obligation is not directly related to the privatisation. Provision of the universal service obligation can be continued under direction of legislation, irrespective of whether or not Telstra is publicly or privately owned. What I am concerned about is that privatisation will inevitably place the ongoing provision of the USO under tremendous pressure along with other regulations, such as those on pricing, which are presently imposed on Telstra.

Furthermore, there is presently much debate about the optimal means for delivering the universal service obligation. A number of industry commentators have called for the removal of cross‐subsidies as the means of financing community service obligations. Instead, they advocate funding them out of budget revenue—in other words, a welfare approach. The danger with this is that, as soon as you transfer payment for the USO to the budget, it will make it far more vulnerable for elimination or reduction than if it is paid for directly by carriers. As soon as governments start looking for somewhere to save a few extra dollars, you can be sure the USO will come up for review.

I have no doubt that private owners of a commercially focused company whose sole objective is to maximise profits would wholeheartedly agree that this is a good thing. The fact is it is quite legitimate for private shareholders to expect management and the board to seek to maximise profits and to lobby the government to remove any regulatory impediments to this aim. The government is kidding itself if it thinks a privatised Telstra is not going to be working very hard to get rid of cross subsidisation and the USO.

BREAK.PARA: It is equally legitimate for the community to expect the government to pursue social objectives in the provision of telecommunication services. This inherent tension cannot be easily dismissed or willed away and will only be exacerbated by privatisation. A privatised Telstra would be governed by a board of directors acting not in the national interest, or in the interests of rural and remote communities, but in the interest of the company.

We should not be fooled into believing that what is best for the company will coincide with what is best for the nation. Let us not forget that it will end up being owned by a select group of domestic elite and foreign shareholders. This company would be one of Australia's largest and would wield tremendous economic and political clout, and Australian governments have not exactly proved themselves resistant to corporate lobbying from that big end of town. It is not hard to see a government—particularly one determined to portray itself as friendly to business—caving in to lobbying by a powerful, private Telstra.

What this adds up to is that, if we go down the privatisation track, we run the high risk of ultimately losing our ability to set, maintain and deliver community service obligations in the national interest. It is not merely the existing universal service obligation which needs to be safeguarded. The universal service obligation is out of date. Reaffirming the existing USO, as the government has promised, will not provide a world class consumer framework; nor will it ensure that they have access to vital communication services, which are essential for actively participating in today's society. It needs to be upgraded if we are to avoid creating a new apartheid—an apartheid of the information rich and the information poor. I will be looking for ways to upgrade the universal service obligation to ensure a fair, equitable and, most importantly, affordable outcome for all Australians, regardless of where they live.

The bill also promises a customer service guarantee to establish mandatory service levels in a number of areas. This is a fairly obvious admission that privatisation, of itself, is not going to deliver the right sorts of outcomes and that some level of regulation is necessary to ensure improved customer outcomes. But these sorts of guarantees and service obligations are not dependent on ownership. The Democrats are keen to see the government implement a mandatory set of appropriate customer service guarantees, irrespective of who owns Telstra.

The Senate Telstra inquiry revealed that major consumer groups in Australia have concerns with the customer service guarantee. They say, and with good reason, that they have not been adequately consulted in their development. The Australian Consumers Association, the Consumers Telecommunications Network, the Communications Law Centre and the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman all highlighted ways in which the guarantee could be improved.

The government also promised to address issues of widespread community concern such as aerial cabling and the siting of mobile phone towers. Consumers have voiced their concern about the cost implications of unnecessary infrastructure duplication. Residents have complained and indeed have taken to the streets in protest over the health implications of telephone towers and the visual impacts of aerial cabling. But, as yet, as we know, the government has done nothing.

The Democrats asked for the Senate Telstra inquiry to consider these matters and it was flooded with submissions. All opposed aerial cabling and the degradation of the environment. The government has dismissed these concerns as being irrelevant. From a government that claims they want to privatise Telstra to benefit consumers, we think this is the height of hypocrisy. It does not require much wisdom to see that appropriate environment and planning regulations are liable to be traded off by the government in pursuit of a higher sale price. These concerns need to be addressed immediately—not some day long away in the future—and I will do all in my power to see that they are addressed.

In summary, the Australian Democrats will be voting against the sale. The crunch will come if the government is called upon to provide consumers with a world class consumer framework in the absence of a change of ownership. We will be look to other parties to support us in this. Any reluctance to take that step will show these proposed guarantees for what they really are—a bribe through which to garner public support for an unpopular privatisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the sale of Telstra, and for very good reason. This has been done over many times and the government has always tried to convince not only the senators in here but the public generally that its partial sale of Telstra will have no effect. The government says that it will put in place mechanisms to protect the consumers and users of telecommunications in this country, but the reality will be something different.

SPEECH.PARA: You only have to look back in history to the sale of other public assets to realise that at the end of the day the government will have no capacity or any legal right to deny the new private shareholders in Telstra their opportunity to maximise their investments. Sooner or later the argument will come up about their rights. There will be arguments from the government, whoever the government may be at that time, that the universal service obligations and requirements on Telstra to install ongoing services and provide new services as part of a cross-subsidised or part subsidised process should come to an end.

One has to question the coalition government's stand on providing for rural and regional Australia the maintenance and improvement of services when it then turns around and proceeds down the track of privatising one of the most fundamentally important service providers in the country. Clearly, the people do not want this to happen. They have demonstrated that through various polls that have been conducted. Also, they do not want any funding for environment policies attached to the sale of Telstra. The government over a very short space of time has been dealing the funding cards off the bottom of the deck as far as the environment is concerned, taking more and more of the funding dollars away very quietly and secretly in an effort to place greater emphasis on, and put more pressure on conservation groups to support, the partial sale.

The conservation groups must be really smarting over the way this government has dealt with environmental matters in the six months or so that it has been in office. We have plenty of examples. The most recent was yesterday with the regulations for the export woodchip licences. Clearly, all conservation groups and a great number of other people concerned about the environment were duped by the coalition prior to the election. They voted in the belief that they would see the maintenance of at least existing funding limits for the environment and that, if there were to be any additional funding from the sale of a public asset, it would have been additional. But that is not the case.

The other aspect you have to consider—I know it has been said many times before—is why you would sell a public asset like Telstra that has such a great capacity to provide funds for the government. It had record earnings in its last financial year and has paid huge dividends to the government. And not only that. With regard to the provision of services throughout the country, and I refer back to the cross-subsidisation issue, in my state alone it is in excess of $9 million. Yet we still do not have the level of services that we might like to have in Tasmania with regard to mobile phone services and other services.

If Telstra is going to be the main player in the game, then it will be important that any government have the capacity to direct it at some point in time to maintain equity in the provision of services to communities throughout Australia. It is fairly evident, even with the current circumstances as they relate to pay TV and other services that are being provided in some areas of the country at the moment, that those companies doing that, even Telstra, do not have any real plans to go to areas that will be deemed to be not profitable. That is a good indicator if, at the end of the day, you sell part of Telstra. We should not forget that the coalition has always had a policy of the complete sale of Telstra.

TALK.START.PARA: —What? The only one that had that was Keating. Keating was the only one who had that policy.

—That is a fact, Senator Panizza; there is no doubt about that. You only have to read back through some of your policy documents to clearly understand what your position was. I can recall one or two letters that I have seen from when you people were in opposition from shadow ministers with regard to what was proposed for Telstra. That is of great concern to the public of Australia and there has been concern with regard to the sale of other assets. You people in opposition say, `Well, you sold the Commonwealth Bank and you sold Qantas.' But the circumstances were totally different. We introduced competition. In terms of the Commonwealth Bank, we have a Reserve Bank of Australia. We have much greater competition following deregulation of the financial system. It would have been unfair to the Commonwealth Bank for it not to have been sold. So from that point of view, the circumstances are totally different.

BREAK.PARA: Australian Airlines and Qantas were merged to create greater competition. We all know that air fares have stayed down and that air travel is increasing. So the circumstances there are totally different and the argument does not hold. What is holding with the Australian people, and why I think at the end of the day we will see this bill ultimately defeated, is that Australians do not want this to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —They like buying shares in their national companies.

—Senator, I hope you have a good argument for the people in Tasmania, and particularly the people in Bass. Your colleague, the member for Bass, Mr Smith, has no argument because he spends most of his time in Sydney. `The member for Sydney', he ought to be called. The people want this bill defeated.
—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —As was foreshadowed in the House of Representatives, the opposition will support this bill for two good reasons. First of all, the concepts embodied in the legislation were in fact concepts foreshadowed by the former government and, secondly, we still feel that the two major concepts in the legislation are worthy of support.

SPEECH.PARA: Of those two major components of the bill, the first relates to a minor amendment to the Defence Services Homes Act 1918 which will ensure that borrowers will have their rights protected when all the states and territories adopt a common consumer code. We are talking here about Westpac Banking taking up the services of lending in this respect. We wanted to ensure that Westpac, in terms of its legal obligations under the Defence Services Home Act 1918, will comply with the requirements of the Consumer Credit Code. We support this because of the enhanced rights that it gives to those who are in a contractual arrangement with Westpac.

The second component relates to an amendment to the Veterans' Entitlement Act 1986. This amendment was once again foreshadowed whilst we were in government. It is an amendment which ensures that, when a veteran dies of a previously established war caused disability, the veteran's dependant will be automatically eligible for a pension without having to re‐establish the relationship between the death and the war service. We saw this as an initiative of importance to the veteran community and we foreshadowed it before the election. We now support this measure which will implement that decision announced before the election.

In supporting the second component of this legislation, we also recognised that the bill will do away with unnecessary uncertainty and frustration that the dependants of veterans who die of war caused disabilities often endure. It is a compassionate step which has been welcomed by the ex‐service community. Having said that, I do not need to prolong the debate in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALKER.NAME: Senator NEWMAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Social Security and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to thank Senator Bolkus for supporting the legislation. Having been a former shadow minister for Veterans Affairs, I well understand that, whilst these are in some way small measures, they will be important to veterans and their widows. I am delighted to see these measures passing into legislation and I thank the opposition for its support.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 May, on motion by Senator Kemp:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to support the Health Insurance Amendment Bill 1996. The previous Labor government took steps to combat the decline in participation in childhood immunisation and vaccination. An initiative of Labor was the establishment of an Australian childhood immunisation register.

SPEECH.PARA: Levels of childhood immunisation have been declining for some years. The proportion of immunised children decreased from 54.1 per cent in 1989‐90 to 52.1 per cent in 1990‐91, and this has been the continuing trend for some years. That drop occurred in just one year. There is some debate about what the cause of this decline has been, but there is some view in the community that the inconvenience and possible side effects of immunisation may no longer outweigh the risk that is avoided by that immunisation. Also, there tends to be a continuing view in the community that the less medical intervention there is the better it is for individuals.

BREAK.PARA: The fact is that this trend has been a major problem for the community. As a result, the incidence of childhood diseases such as measles, whooping cough and rubella have been on the increase. The sad thing is that, even though these diseases are generally a minor inconvenience and are generally thought of as such in the community, over the ten‐year period between 1983 and 1993 41 deaths occurred as a result of measles, a fact that I do not think many people would appreciate.

As a result of this problem, the previous Labor government put in place a twofold strategy in order to combat it. The first was an education campaign to ensure that parents were aware of the necessity to vaccinate and the second was the introduction of the register that this legislation is now putting into place. Originally the 18‐month trial was put in place by regulation but in light of the success of this program, it is now seen as appropriate to put it into primary legislation and I am completely in accord with that view.

It is worth noting that in the six months between 1 January 1996 and 30 June 1996 there were over one million notifications of vaccines that had been administered recorded on the register and there are over 11,000 doctors and medical practices and 256 councils now providing data. I fully endorse this amendment and urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is good to see that there is a great deal of bipartisan support on this issue. It is a vital issue. There is no doubt that, as Senator Neal has pointed out, there has been an unnecessary increase in the incidence of, particularly, rubella, measles and whooping cough. As she points out, there have been deaths. As she did not mention, but I am sure implied, there have also been a number of children suffering long-term brain damage from those particular diseases, in particular from measles—far more than have ever been accounted for as caused by the immunisation process itself.

PARA.BREAK: There is a bit of folklore around the community at present which says that immunisation is harmful. The facts are that the evi dence to correlate immunisation with deaths—in Australia in particular—is incredibly scanty. There is very little evidence, if any at all, to indicate that there is a correlation between the two. Certainly, there is a temporal relationship, but beyond that it has been impossible to prove a correlation.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no question at all in my mind, and in the mind of every sensible person, that we should encourage a 100 per cent immunisation rate in our children. This legislation will encourage that. It has been a bipartisan approach and I am delighted that my colleagues in the chamber have supported this issue.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Yesterday, in reference to Tunboa Pty Ltd, did the Minister for Finance say that he had `transferred my interest in that company to my former partner in 1986'? Why then did Mr Fahey on nine occasions declare in his declaration of pecuniary interests to the New South Wales parliament that he was a shareholder in this company? Is it true that at a doorstop earlier today Mr Fahey blamed a personal staff member for continuing to lodge Tunboa Pty Ltd as a pecuniary interest? Did Mr Fahey sign these declaration forms, or has he requested the police to investigate the possible forgery of his signature on these forms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Sherry, I think there was a touch of drama at the end of your question which I do not think was merited. I have a brief here on the particular issue raised by Senator Sherry. I am advised that Mr Fahey divested his interest in Tunboa in 1986, a decade ago, and well before he entered the federal parliament. Tunboa was a service company which was, and is, worth next to nothing.

ANSWER.PARA: Mr Fahey's business partner failed to amend the Australian Securities Commission entry; hence, the entry incorrectly states that Mr Fahey has an interest in the company. Mr Fahey's business partner has written to Mr Fahey confirming this. He also confirms that Mr Fahey has received no benefit from Tunboa since 1986.

Mr Fahey inadvertently forgot to remove the entry from the New South Wales parliament's registry of interests. Mr Fahey regrets that he overlooked removing the entry from the New South Wales registry of interests. Everything Mr Fahey said in his letter to the PM yesterday stands today. That is the entirety of the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator Kemp, given your detailed knowledge of Mr Fahey and Tunboa, is it a fact that only yesterday Mr Fahey resigned as a director of Tunboa Pty Ltd?
—I have nothing to add to the answer I have given.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications and the Arts. What is the government's position regarding the provision of funding for arts related activities to trade union bodies? How does this compare to the position of the previous Labor administration?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Communications and the Arts

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Calvert for that very important question. No doubt everyone in the community would accept that there is a responsibility for governments to provide funding to various arts bodies in order to ensure that people have every opportunity to give expression to their creative endeavours. There are a number of situations in which the marketplace does not fulfil the need, and therefore governments have a role. But what is of great concern is when a party as ideological as the Labor Party thinks a legitimate vehicle for funding arts is the trade union movement.

BREAK.PARA: My colleague Senator Short put a question on notice to the previous minister for the arts, Mr Lee, to ascertain to what extent the trade union movement had been used as a vehicle for arts funding. The question was put on notice on 25 September last year. Not only did Senator Short not get an answer within the required 30 days; he actually did not get an answer at all before the last election.

You ask yourself, `Why did Mr Lee wait for five months?' Or, in fact, `Why would he have waited forever?' The answer is that Mr Lee simply was not game to tell the public the disgraceful facts of the matter, because the facts are that, between 1994-95 and 1995-96, nearly $800,000 in arts funding was supplied to the ALP's main funding source—the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —How much?

—It was $772,000, in fact. You can understand why Mr Lee was very reluctant to disclose this sort of information. He knew that the ALP would be judged guilty by the court of public opinion. In other words, the facts could not stand the light of day. This is simply another arts rort.

BREAK.PARA: I can give examples of where these funds were spent. There was $28,700 given to the Queensland branch of the ACTU for a poster competition and exhibition. The Tasmanian TLC got nearly $200,000—$199,925, in fact—for a variety of projects, ranging from a celebration of pulping in Burnie to a photographic exhibition connecting time through sight. As part of the overall total, the Tasmanian TLC got two grants of $48,000 each to employ a community cultural development organiser. The ACT Trades and Labour Council—and no doubt Senator Lundy was very grateful for this—also did exceptionally well. It got grants totalling $122,420 during the same period for two exhibitions.

This is typical of a party that does not believe in free creative endeavour. It believes in manipulating artists by requiring them to express their cultural aspirations through the prism of the ALP's ideology. What it was doing was no doubt encouraging those who wanted to perpetuate myths about heroic worker struggles, anti-capitalist propaganda and all the sorts of slogans that can pass for art if you are in the trade union movement.

We regard this as totally unacceptable. Our view is that the arts ought to flourish in an environment where government is not pulling the strings and simply saying, `If you toe the line, we'll give you money.' We all know why the Labor Party does it. They do it so that the trade union movement can pay them back in spades at election time.

Our approach is quite different to that. We are not Sydneycentric like Mr Keating. We did not take the view that it was okay to spend $150 million if you did not like the view of the Cahill Expressway. We would rather put that money into regional arts funding.

I call on the ALP to dissociate itself from its failed leader. The captain might be off the team but the rest of the side is well and truly still out there. If it has not dissociated itself from his approach, we can assume that Labor still thinks that it is legitimate to use those sorts of rorts, to use that sort of government control of the arts and any other area it can get its hands on.
It simply is not good enough. Once again, it is a fundamental conflict of interest. The sooner you recognise it, the better chance you have of getting back into the political game.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Kemp as the Minister representing the Minister for Finance. Given the fact that Mr Fahey has said that he had nothing to do with Tunboa Pty Ltd in the last 10 years, why is it that the annual return of that company shows him as secretary of that company from 21 November 1980 until yesterday? Did Mr Fahey, on any occasion in the last 10 years, sign the annual return of that company or the directors' report contained within the statutory financial statements of that company which are required, in his capacity as director, to be lodged with the Australian Securities Commission after the end of each financial year?
—This is the second question we have had on this particular issue. I do not know whether Senator Conroy—

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Thank you Madam President. As I said, this is the second question we have had on this particular issue, and I can repeat—
—That is the second time you have said it.

—If Senator Conroy was not listening, and if Senator Faulkner was not listening, I am happy to repeat what I said earlier on. Mr Fahey divested his interest in Tunboa in 1986, a decade ago, and well before he entered the federal parliament. That is the advice I have received in a brief. Tunboa was a service company which was, and is, worth next to nothing.

BREAK.PARA: As I also mentioned, Senator Conroy—you might care to listen the first time round so I do not have to repeat it all the time—his business partner failed to amend the Australian Securities Commission entry, hence the entry incorrectly states that Mr Fahey has an interest in the company. Mr Fahey's business partner has written to Mr Fahey confirming that—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why did he forward his change of address?

—This is very important, Senator Ray, so you might care to listen to this. Rather than shouting out all the time, you might care to listen to this. He confirms that Mr Fahey has received no benefit from Tunboa since 1986.
—When are you going to answer the question?
—You obviously were not tuned in either, Senator Cook, so I can say to you that Mr Fahey inadvertently forgot to remove his interests from the New South Wales parliament's register of interests.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections on my left. It is totally disorderly to behave in that fashion.
—Thank you, Madam President. Might I also comment that if we had less shouting out and more listening on the other side we would not have the answers to questions needing to be repeated.
—Senator Kemp, apply yourself to the question, please.

—As always, Madam President. Mr Fahey inadvertently forgot to remove the entry from the New South Wales parliament's register of interests. As I said, Mr Fahey regrets that he overlooked removing the entry from that registry. There you are—I have answered the question, I answered the question earlier and I have nothing more to add.
—A supplementary question: why then was the return changed five times in the last nine years, including his address and details?

—Senator Conroy, seeing you do seem to have a particular interest in this matter, and to save you from wasting some more time in the Senate, I will bring your question to the attention of Mr Fahey and see whether he feels that he has anything that he wishes to add.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Minister, I wonder if by any chance you listened to AM this morning and heard the opposition spokesman on Aboriginal and islander affairs, Mr Daryl Melham, make that quite disgusting and most inappropriate parallel between the Jewish Holocaust and the removal of Aboriginal children? Minister, I wonder if you could set the record straight and explain the government's position in relation to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission's inquiry into Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children's separation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Macdonald. It is a very important question, Madam President, in relation to the government's response to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. There is no doubt that the past practices of removing Aboriginal children from their families were appalling.

BREAK.PARA: The Attorney‐General provided the Commonwealth government's submission to the inquiry last week. In that submission, the Commonwealth argues that it is inappropriate to attempt to provide cash compensation for past actions which are unacceptable by today's standards. The government's approach is to respond to current needs by designing and delivering programs aimed at particular areas of disadvantage. The government will consider the recommendations of the inquiry when they are presented.

What I am seriously concerned about, however, is the language of hate that has crept into the opposition's vocabulary in the sensitive area of race relations in this nation. I am aware of the comments by Mr Melham this morning on ABC radio. In those, he sought to draw parallels between the Jewish Holocaust and the removal of Aboriginal children. In August, we had the sorry spectacle of the opposition leader addressing a union sponsored demonstration outside this place with the words:
This government hates workers. It hates students. It hates Aboriginal people. It hates women who want to work.

Once again, this is the language of hate from those opposite. Yesterday we had that disgraceful behaviour from Senator Bolkus during question time—once again the language of hate from those opposite. I note that after sitting down yesterday—

TALK.START.PARA: —You hate John Howard's guidelines; that's what you hate.
—Senator Faulkner please desist from interjecting and calling out from across the chamber. Senator Herron, have you finished your answer?

—No, I have not, Madam President. I note that after sitting there during question time and denying that he used the words `Why do you hate blackfellas', which I heard distinctly, he quietly returned to the chamber at 5.58 last night, almost four hours after his outburst and denial, to finally concede that he did use those words and to apologise, and then only because it was recorded in Hansard .

BREAK.PARA: This language of hate coming from those opposite is a disgrace. It is only fuelling the current debate. It amounts to cheap and—I might add—offensive political point scoring at the expense of Aboriginal people, those who have made this country their home and those who were born here.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not done one constructive thing in power. You have not done one constructive thing as minister.

—My supplementary question is directed to Senator Herron. I wonder if Senator Herron heard the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, Senator Faulkner, jokingly refer to the removal of Aboriginal children in the same light as Mr Howard's guidelines on shares? I wonder if the minister has any comment about the seriousness of the separation of Aboriginal children and the way the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate treats it so flippantly?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Senator Macdonald. It also gives me an opportunity—
—I said you hate the Prime Minister's guidelines.
—Senator Faulkner, I ask you to cease yelling across the chamber.

—Thank you, Madam President. I did hear Senator Faulkner say that. I also heard Senator Bolkus again this afternoon compound what he did yesterday in his comments. Senator Bolkus, we have done an enormous amount for the Aboriginal people since we took over government because we are not locked into your paradigm. We are progressing on to the future. We have done an enormous amount. We have cleared up the perception—the special auditor's report has demonstrated that and that is going through. We are working constructively with ATSIC for the first time, which did not occur in the previous government. We are meeting on a daily basis with ATSIC and we are progressing to the future. I would hope that it will get through even to the opposition, dense as they are, that we actually won the election on 2 March and we are marching to a different tune from the one that they were.

—My question is directed to Senator Newman as Minister for Social Security. Minister, do you recall your office was reported by the Daily Telegraph on 25 September as saying that Senator Vanstone's phantom family, the Wrights, is still receiving massive welfare payments and that there was nothing the department could do to stop the family receiving welfare payments? Were these statements supported by advice from your department? If not, don't they make you complicit in Senator Vanstone's misrepresentation of the facts?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I deny absolutely that I am in any way complicit with anybody on anything, because I am not a crook.
—No, but she is.
—No, she is not. She is not a crook.
—Oh!
—Order! Senator Newman, resume your seat. Order!
—That is the classic all‐time gaffe!
—Senator Faulkner! Order!

—Madam President, what I was trying to refer to was the allegation implicit in the question—that somehow the actions of Senator Vanstone were crooked. Senator Vanstone, to my knowledge, has been honourable in this whole issue. Having said that, the means test, which was the basis of the questioning at the estimates committee hearing, was introduced by the previous government, and rightly so.

ANSWER.PARA: Nobody can in all conscience endorse rorting of the social security system or the Austudy system at the expense of the battlers so that people who have means are not providing for themselves where they can. That is the basis of this issue. Senator Vanstone has supported the attempts to make sure that those who can afford to provide for their own children's education are doing so.

I and my department also are concerned that there is the potential, which was not addressed by the previous government, for some people to be accessing social security who should not be entitled to it. We believe that we should be supporting the needy, not the greedy. That surely is what we should be concerned about now.

I understood, when I saw an article in the Sydney Daily Telegraph, that there may have been some inaccuracies in the assessment of what entitlements a family known as the Wright family might have been receiving. My office contacted Senator Vanstone's office the day that appeared and advised that we would like to look at the matter further, which we did. At that time, I put out a press release saying what we believed the situation to be.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, I certainly was not suggesting that either you or Senator Vanstone was crooked, as you suggested. I was seeking information. I would like to ask: was your `dob in a dole bludger' hotline used in terms of the information about the Wright family? Did you have any reference to that hotline? Did you draw your department's advice to Senator Vanstone's attention—at least by providing her with a copy of your press release—or to the attention of the Prime Minister's office? If not, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Social Security

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a bit of a stupid sort of supplementary, isn't it? Firstly, there is no such thing as a `dob in a bludger' hotline. That is a media headline, but it is nothing I have ever used. It is totally irrelevant to the issue at hand. The employers contact unit is nothing to do with this issue. That is really what it boils down to. Secondly, my office was in contact, as I said, with Senator Vanstone's office over this issue.
—On the 25th.
—Do you want the answer? Later the two departments discussed the matter and sorted out the issues.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Minister, you have changed the parameters for woodchipping, you have changed the ceilings on licences and you have changed the regulations. Will you clearly indicate to the Senate whether you intend to change, or are in the process of changing, the conditions on woodchip licences? Can you assure us that the conditions on last year's licences will be the same as the conditions on this year's licences?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —The only information I can give you, Senator, in respect of the woodchip licences is that laid out in the regulations. In the absence of any change to those regulations, I assume—but I will check this with the minister as I do not have a brief on it—there would be no change in the conditions.

—I thank the minister. When you check with the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, could you in particular ask whether there will be any changes to the logging of rainforests and whether you will be issuing licences for rainforest chips; and whether there will be any change to the conditions relating to the clearing of land for agricultural purposes—in other words, whether you will issue licences for timber felled through clearing land for agriculture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the conditions relating to the issuing of export licences for woodchips are spelt out exactly in the regulations.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, are you aware that the Prime Minister's Guide to key elements of ministerial responsibility requires that, amongst other things, ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the parliament or the public; any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity; and any answer which may be found to be incorrect should be corrected as soon as the error is found using the procedures of the house concerned? Is it not true that Senator Newman sounded the alarm about the `Wright family' on 25 September, as Senator Newman just said in her answer? Why then, given the spectacular coverage of your scam by the media, did you not immediately set the public record straight? Why did you not set the parliamentary record straight last Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, or Monday or Tuesday of this week?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Crowley for that question because it gives me an opportunity to highlight one aspect of the Australian Labor Party which was completely rejected by the Australian people at the last election, and that is an element of hypocrisy.
—Answer the question.

—I am answering the question. This example closely parallels an experience of Senator Schacht—one of your ministers, Senator Crowley—who was inadvertently advised by his department and gave an incorrect answer to an estimates committee.

ANSWER.PARA: What did Senator Schacht do? Do you think that when he first found this out he immediately set in train the process to advise either the committee or the parliament of the error? Do you think he did that? No, he did not. How did the parliament find out about this error? Because somebody asked Senator McMullan a question and Senator Schacht had to slink in on taking note of the answer and admit that he had made a mistake before the estimates committee.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't feign not knowing. This was referred to the Privileges Committee and you would remember it well. So let's not pretend you don't know about this.
—Order! There are too many interjections.
—The Privileges Committee gave a very good report. We will put you there and see how you go.

—Don't get oversensitive. Of course, reluctantly at the end of his speech in taking note of the answer, Senator Schacht said, `Yes, this thing was a tax and not a charge. And, yes, legislation will have to be introduced'—which was the opposite of what he told the committee.

BREAK.PARA: This was sent off to the Privileges Committee. And what did that committee say? The Privileges Committee said that Senator Schacht was not at fault because he had not deliberately misled the estimates committee. They even concluded that he did not really mean to mislead the Senate, as they believed he had, in taking note of the question. They gave him the full benefit of the doubt and said that he was misinformed. They did say, however, that he should have notified the estimates committee—and he did not. He actually said, `We'll go through all of this again when the estimates committee next sits.'

What have I done? I have been notified and I make no secret of it. Senator Newman's office contacted my office and said, `Look, we think something is wrong here', and ever since then our offices have been sharing information trying to get to the bottom of the problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!
—It is true.

BREAK.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot get through this, Madam President, if you do not invite those who asked the question to let me answer it.
—Stop the clock. Order! Proceed, Senator Vanstone.

—In relation to that matter, Senator Crowley, I did not deliberately mislead the estimates committee. I ask you to accept that. Although you so ungenerously last night—when I had written to the committee and apologised and, in response to a question, indicated that if an apology was required in this chamber I would give it—nonetheless went on PM and said that I still rejected that there had been some misleading. That is not the case.

BREAK.PARA: I set about getting the facts. It was not an easy task getting all the facts. I will be making a statement after question time when I will give you a chronology of events and such documents as I can so that you can make your own assessment. But before you point the finger, why don't you look at what your minister did and judge me by the standards you judged him by?

TALK.START.PARA: —Very little of that answer, Madam President, went to the question asked, so, in supplementary I ask: minister, notwithstanding all that you said then, would you have corrected the record in this place if Senator Carr had not asked his question yesterday? Is it true, as reported by the Sydney Morning Herald this morning, that, `Within two days of Senator Vanstone's claim being made public, her department was referring all media inquiries to the minister's office, suggesting knowledge that the claim was erroneous'? Finally, if you yesterday said that you came into this place to give an unreserved apology, how does that sit with you saying at the end of your interview last night, `A day or two here or there, what's the big deal'? How does that sit with `immediately' correcting the record if it is wrong?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley, as I have indicated to you—and I am not even trying to make any secret of this—of course, when this matter received media coverage, which, incidentally, was not at my instigation—
—Oh yes, it was.
—No, it was not.
—Yes, it was.
—Well, you provide the proof of that.
—Who asked the questions and who put out the media release?

—Not me; I didn't put out a media release. Senator Crowley, what you need to know is that the matter was raised on the day that Senator Newman indicated. Since then we have been trying to get to the bottom of the matter. It is not appropriate for me, finding that there has been an error, to immediately accept—even if I get an answer immediately, which I did not—the information. It behoves me to properly check that information.

ANSWER.PARA: I actually find that, as late as last night, I have been given more information by the department. So perhaps I should have waited longer to get more information from the department as to the so‐called Wright family that was put to me as being a good example of a family that was caught by your actual means test. So I would say to you that I have done everything I could. The error was pointed out. We tried to get to the bottom of what the errors were. Once I was satisfied of that, I notified the relevant committee. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. There is encouraging evidence that Australia's minerals and energy sector is playing a pivotal role in the accelerating economic growth in the East Asia and South Pacific regions. Can the minister indicate whether this assessment is solidly based and what contribution the minerals and energy sector will make to Australia's growth and prosperity in both the short and long term.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Sandy Macdonald for his question. I think it indicates the seriousness with which we are treating the economic mess bequeathed to us and the Australian people after 13 years of Labor mismanagement. There can be no doubt that the minerals and energy sector will continue to be one of the main drivers of growth and prosperity for all Australians into the future. Without the wealth created by the minerals and energy sector, there would be considerably less funds available for the broad range of state and Commonwealth programs, including those directed towards environmental protection.

ANSWER.PARA: Mineral and energy resources are our largest single export earner, accounting for 60 per cent of all commodity exports and 35 per cent of all exports of goods and services. Total earnings from minerals and energy exports are expected to rise to a record $37 billion in 1996‐97. In addition to company and PAYE tax, the minerals and energy sector contributes about $2.2 billion a year in royalties to the states, as well as, in most instances, providing their own infrastructure at no cost to the taxpayer. It employs over 400,000 people directly and indirectly in the economy and contributes six per cent to gross domestic product.

BREAK.PARA: The sector is a major driver of investment, accounting for over 30 per cent of total new investment last year. I know from my discussions with investors and buyers overseas that there is great potential for more investment, more jobs, more income and more growth.

To achieve these outcomes, however, Australia must create a climate of greater stability and predictability in areas such as land access, and improve coordination of environmental and other policies by all levels of government. Continued micro‐economic reform, including the ready availability of competitively priced energy, is necessary to promote greater investment in downstream value adding projects. These are all priority areas for reform by the Howard coalition government.

I think it is worth noting that in today's world investment is very competitive. From an investment perspective, there are no international boundaries. Investment is very similar to electricity: it will always flow to the lowest point of resistance.

There are currently 25 major minerals processing projects—value adding, I might add—in Australia at advanced stages of planning and development, involving a potential capital expenditure of over $20 billion. If these value adding projects are to proceed, they have the potential to generate an additional $7 billion a year in export income.

In addition, there are another 90 mining projects at various stages of development. For example, BHP's $450 million Cannington base metal project in Queensland is under construction. Newcrest have committed $420 million to the development of the Acadia Hill gold project in New South Wales. Anaconda have completed a feasibility study on a $900 million investment in developing the Murrin Murrin nickel deposit in Western Australia. Shell have committed over $500 million to the development of a new coal mine at Moranbah in Queensland. And so the list goes on. A large potential project worth particular mention is the development of the multi‐
billion dollar LNG project, in regard to which a press statement was released today, and which will mean over $1 billion in export revenue to Australia.

The government will do all that it can to facilitate these projects without compromising the high environmental standards that we expect the industry to meet. The minerals and energy sector will continue to be a major export earner for Australia. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Jacinta

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Yesterday in question time, when Senator Carr asked you a question about the so‐called Wright family, you replied:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . what the department had done was taken an actual family but had added a couple of kids. . .

Which child or children did the department add to the so‐called Wright family? Was it the six‐month‐old baby, which provides $8,500 to the Wright family? Was it the 14‐year‐old child, which provides $3,000 to the Wright family? Or was it both children, providing $11,500 of the supposed $15,000 provided to the Wright family? Also, Minister, can you confirm that your departmental secretary, Mr Hollway, advised you of the bogus nature of the family on 26 September?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the senator for the question. It gives me an opportunity to make two points again. Firstly, I remind you of one of the reasons I think you lot lost office; that is, the hypocritical approach you take to things. I raised this example with you of where a previous minister, Senator Schacht, was, I believe, misinformed; he provided the incorrect information and subsequently failed to advise the committee or the Senate until he was caught out. That is when he decided to come clean. That matter was referred to the Privileges Committee; the report is there if you would like to read it, Senator.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated that what Senator Newman told you was correct. She—or someone from her office—contacted the office to indicate she thought there was some miscalculation vis‐a‐vis the social security amounts appropriated to the so-called Wright family. I have also indicated to the Senate that, following that, my office and hers—and, if I did not add before, my department—were busily working amongst ourselves and between each other, department to department, office to office, to try to get the correct information.

I have further indicated that following question time I will make a statement on this matter. I have indicated to you that as late as last night I received more information from the department, and I believe that I have followed the appropriate course of action. But let me run through it for you, Senator, if you feel it will help in any particular way. If you want advance notice of what is coming later, I will give it to you.

The Wright family example was used in an estimates committee hearing on 23 September. There was significant coverage given to that matter on 25 September and, as I have indicated to you, not as a consequence of my seeking to give the matter some particular profile.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not from your press secretary?

—Neither me nor my office. On Thursday, 26 September, the secretary to the department undertook inquiries and prepared for me a draft letter and a press release. Later on that Thursday I understand that the Stop Press Hansard was available on the computers in the offices and the normal Hansard was available on the Friday for checking. On Friday, 27 September, the secretary's office faxed a minute with an amended letter and a press release to the Canberra office.

ANSWER.PARA: On Monday and Tuesday of the following week, the office was still checking some of these issues and raised the matter with the Clerk—it may have been one of the assistant clerks; I am not sure, it was not me who did it—as to whether, if this letter was sent, it would appropriately discharge the duties. It was suggested that an amendment be made to the letter to Senator Tierney to ensure that it was circulated to all members. That amendment was made to the letter. The letter was then E-mailed to my ministerial office and E-mailed to Adelaide where I was on Thursday and Friday of that week attending to correspondence and departmental briefs. The letter was signed by me on Friday the 4th, came back to Canberra with all the correspondence and briefings that had been done in Adelaide on the Thursday and Friday and, I am advised, was sent on the Wednesday to Senator Tierney. I was further advised on Wednesday the 16th by the Clerk; I will not try to put words in his mouth, but you have seen the Clerk's advice that I have basically done what I could to get the correct information.

Despite having done all that, and it was a considerable effort to get the right information on this matter, which I was happy to outlay, I nonetheless advised that further information was provided to me last night.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vanstone, your time has expired.

—I ask a supplementary question. Minister, even despite your explanation that this was a bogus family, isn't it a fact that, because of the introduction of the Austudy actual means test introduced by Labor in the 1995-96 budget, the so-called Wright family would not be eligible for the remaining $3,500—that is, the extra kid that was not added—which was supposedly paid in Austudy for this family's 16‐year‐old child?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much for that question. Can I just respond to an interjection of Senator Ray's, which was, `Well, you will have to sack 3,000 public servants.'
—I said, `Why did you?'
—Why didn't I? Because 3,000 public servants have not made a mistake.
—That is right; but you sacked them all.
—Order!

—I am actually answering a question from another senator, through you, Madam President. The department freely admits it made a mistake. The Prime Minister has read to the House of Representatives the first paragraph of a letter sent today by Mr Hollway to the secretary of the estimates committee. He read the first sentence, which says:

ANSWER.PARA: I am writing to you direct on the matter of the `Wright family' because the fault clearly lies with the Department.

I have done everything subsequent to that that I believe I can to get the right information. Senator Ray, if you think every time a public servant makes a mistake, they should be sacked, good luck to you, but it is not my view.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I raise a point of order. I ask the minister to table the letter from Mr Hollway that the minister has quoted from.

—Madam President, that is not a point of order. Senator Ray, I have indicated several times to people on your side that, following question time, I will make a brief statement and I will table all of this for you, okay—the whole box and dice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Chemical Storage Complex at Point Lillias

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and it concerns the proposed siting of a chemical storage complex at Point Lillias, an important Ramsar site in Victoria. Has the Victorian state government yet forwarded to the federal government its case for urgent national interest and compensatory habitat for the excision of the Point Lillias Peninsula from the Port Phillip (western shoreline) Ramsar listing? Will this document be made public? Further, has the minister yet notified the Ramsar bureau that a Ramsar site is about to be degraded, as required by the protocol of the Montreau convention?

—I certainly have not done the second. I think your party wrote to the Ramsar bureau to allege that that was a fact; so there would hardly be any point, even if I accepted the premise of the second part of the question.
