I personally have not yet received the case for urgent national interest or the alternative compensatory habitat. I have been waiting on it. It is to come from two separate Victorian ministers. I will ask again when I get back to the office to see whether it has come into the department but, when I last asked, the ball was still in their court.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for his answer. I ask: will this document be made public, if and when it arrives? Is the minister aware that a case for excision of a Ramsar site has only ever been agreed to once before in the world, and this was in Belgium where there were no other alternatives?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —It is my understanding that it has only rarely been approved, but I thought it was more than once. The tests are set out—the urgent national interest, as you say. It seems to me from my visits to Melbourne and certainly from the estimates committee the other night that it is the view of the Labor opposition that it is important to have this chemical storage facility moved out of the suburbs of Melbourne. The question is: where should it be relocated?

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Allison will be aware of what has occurred over the last few years in that regard. It was going to go to Point Wilson but then that was utilised for an armaments depot. Then it was suggested that it should be at Point Lillias, and that has gone through a Victorian government assessment process to which my department contributed. The contribution of my department and their concerns are on the public record, and those concerns were made public with my agreement. I do not think there is any dispute about the difficulties in relation to the matter. I am still concerned about it. If documents can be made public, I will make them public. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. I ask the minister whether she is aware that the Reverend Harry Herbert, General Secretary of the Uniting Church Board for Social Responsibility, had this to say about your use of the so-called `Wright' family: `It matters because Senator Vanstone and other people'—I want to make sure you hear this, so I will pause.

BREAK.PARA: Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask the clerk to reset the clocks for Senator Neal to recommence her question.

—Reverend Herbert said: `It matters because Senator Vanstone and other people in the Federal Government, for quite some time, have been campaigning against people on social security. They've been spreading the idea that there are all these rorters in social security. And in fact, that's a reflection on everybody in Australia who gets their benefits from social security. And this, I think, is the crowning achievement of Senator Vanstone, that she should indulge in the campaign to the extent that she would even make up a fictitious example and put it around as if it really was a true case.' Minister, how do you respond to this accusation? Doesn't it indicate that you were just plain wrong in asserting on PM last night that `not a lot of damage has been done'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to say that I thank Senator Neal for that question but I do not. I think you will find in the question, Madam President—which is often the case in a question or a supplementary from that side—that an offensive assertion was made. I have come into this place on a number of occasions, and I have written to the committee and I have said—

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vanstone, just wait until there is order in the chamber.

—I have said, `Look, the department admits that the so-called Wright family started as a family to which they then made changes.' When I became aware of that, I did all that I could. This has been clearly admitted in here.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Neal, you might take the opportunity in a supplementary to tell me whether you refuse to accept what a senator puts in writing and says in this place on a number of occasions. By saying that I would even make up a fictitious example, are you asserting that you reject what I have said in my letter to Senator Tierney? Are you saying you reject me twice coming into this place and saying that, yes, the department made a mistake and, yes, we have done what we can to try to correct it.

If Senator Neal does not understand that that means I am admitting my department made a mistake; I am admitting that we inadvertently misled the committee; and I am telling you we have done all we could to correct it—why does she still come in here and tell people who are listening that I have deliberately made up a fictitious example? What is the case here, Senator: do you not understand what I have said or are you in your question trying to mislead yet again? That is what I want to hear when Senator Neal gets up, if she has the guts, to ask a supplementary. That is what I want to know.

As to Mr Herbert, if you want the answer to this, I am happy to give it to you. But if you want to have a side discussion with Senator West, I am happy for you to do that too. The bottom line here is that I do not attribute bad faith to Mr Herbert in the way I attribute bad faith to Senator Neal, unless she gets up and says that she accepts what I have told her and offers me an apology for insinuating in this place that I have lied on numerous occasions and deliberately lied to this chamber. I do not attribute that bad faith to Mr Herbert. He probably believes that I did make it up myself and, if so, he has been misinformed. Perhaps I will take the opportunity to write to him. He might have the good grace to write to me and say he was misinformed.

Senator Neal, I invite you to point on the record where I have ever got stuck into social security recipients. There are numerous occasions where I have taken the opportunity to say that social security benefits and Austudy should be going to the most needy. The reason your party introduced an actual means test was that you realised, and properly realised, there were wealthy people who could manipulate their income and assets so as to get both Austudy and social security benefits.
That is the reason you did it and that is the reason we supported you.

But in your supplementary, Senator Neal, this is what I want to hear from you: do you accept the commitment I have given to this chamber that my department gave me the wrong information, that I inadvertently misled the committee and that I have corrected that error?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Vanstone, you should address your remarks through the chair.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I can understand that Senator Vanstone might become confused and agitated in light of the questions, but I must point out to her that the statement was made by Harry Herbert and not me. Further, I would like to ask whether the minister is aware of the swelling popular support for Reverend Herbert's proposal that she should be required to do 100 hours community service explaining social security to people and showing that the overwhelming number of recipients are receiving benefits to which they are rightfully entitled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much, Senator Neal. I am prepared to say that if a senator, and particularly a minister, deliberately made up a fictitious example and deliberately misled a committee Mr Herbert is a bit light in his punishment. If you deliberately mislead a committee you deserve everything you get. There is no question about it. But the point I have made to you is I did not do that, just as Senator Schacht did not do that.

ANSWER.PARA: Everybody makes mistakes. My department regrets the mistake it has made. The secretary has apologised to the committee. I regret that the department made this mistake, but I take responsibility for it. I have tried to fix the problem. I accept that the committee was misled. I have come in here on a number of occasions and told you that. I have told you that after question time I will give you every document that I have explaining this matter. If you do not understand that, I do not know what is wrong with you.

What restrictions are placed on genetic manipulation to avoid the dangers of the inadvertent creation of super‐resistant diseases? What mandatory reporting requirements are there for GMAC, the Genetic Manipulation Advisory Council, to be advised of the risks? What reporting procedures are there for the minister to be kept informed and advised of dangerous incidents or potentially dangerous incidents involving genetically engineered organisms?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Parer, Sen Warwick
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Resources and Energy

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very complex question. I know Senator Harradine feels very strongly about this. I think his views are shared by many people in this chamber. I have no brief from Minister McGauran on this. I will refer the question to him and come back to you.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Do you recall preaching to this chamber on 9 October about the importance of the truth. You stated:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . for voters to cast their vote it must be on the basis of what has actually happened: the truth. There is therefore a very strong interest in the truth being told.

Is it not the truth, as confirmed by your department at estimates, that budget cuts to DEETYA will be around $4.3 billion over four years, university operating grants will be cut by $623.6 million, discretionary funds will be cut by $214.6 million, Austudy will be cut by over $500 million and the Commonwealth will now be funding some 17,000 fewer university places in 1997 and 1998? These are the cuts you described as `just a nick—you would not even put a bandaid on them'. Is this not just another case, as with the phantom Wright family, of you peddling half truths and deceptions? Aren't the vice‐chancellors right in accusing you of not helping debate by pretending that the effect of government changes is less than it is and your statements are unrealistic and mislead the public? (Time expired)

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Murphy for the opportunity of raising, yet again, the mistruths that your lot have been peddling vis-a-vis the higher education budget. What I have said—and I will take this opportunity to repeat it; I thank you very much for that opportunity—is that operating grants for universities are being cut by one per cent of what they were expecting to get next year. That will leave them with more money next year than they had this year. I have consistently argued that it is improper for people to suggest to year 12 students who might want to apply for places that there will be fewer places for them next year. We have undertaken to fund about 5,000 more undergraduate places next year.

ANSWER.PARA: It is true that we have not asked the universities to teach the same number of people for less dollars. What we have said to them is that they can cut load. In order to protect the opportunities for young Australians to have the first crack at higher education, we have said to them that we do not want them to do it in the undergraduate area. We want to maintain the opportunity for young Australians to get that first chance and operate under Labor's HECS system, which we support and where it does not matter how much money you have, you do not have to pay your contribution back until you start earning.

For that reason, we have maintained that. We are actually adding to the number of undergraduate places next year. The drop in places over a period of time will be a drop in postgraduate course work places which you may realise are places that can already be bought. I think it was your government, Senator Murphy, that introduced the opportunity for Australian graduates to do that. The senator sitting next to you chose to pay for his postgraduate education elsewhere. I hope that is not a comment by him on the quality of Australian higher education because it is of exemplary quality.

I am taking the opportunity next week to go to a number of conferences and try to promote Australian higher education overseas. I am going to Malaysia to the first conference of Australian alumni students. As you would know, we have about 11,000 students from Malaysia here each year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you got your answers ready on racism?

—I can't hear you, Senator, I am sorry. I am going to Indonesia for preliminary ministerial meeting discussions. Indonesia also has some close higher education links with us. I am then taking the opportunity to go to the New Horizons conference in India, where we hope to build our educational relationships. Every chance I get I will be making a number of things clear: firstly, we have an excellent higher education system; secondly, anything that is good can still get better; and, thirdly, the cut to operating grants is one per cent of what they were expecting to get next year, leaving them with more than they had this year—that there are more undergraduate places because we want more young Australians to have that chance and that—
—There are 17,000 less.
—There are not 17,000 fewer undergraduate places.
—There are 17,000 less over two years.
—There are not. The cut in places comes, Senator—you do not seem to understand what I have just told you—from postgraduate course work places.
—You are not telling the truth.

—I invite you to withdraw that, Senator. You will regret it if you do not. Senator Carr does not want to. I tell you he has made a misstatement of the facts and I leave him to correct that at another time.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, I congratulate you on the major overseas jaunt that you are going to go on to sell what the vice‐chancellors think we are going to have less of. But, before you do that, you might like to inform the Senate when you are going to respond to the vice‐chancellors' challenge to articulate some form of vision for this sector that is not driven by physical and ideological obsessions and which recognises the importance of higher education in developing Australian society.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, I wish you had asked me that question first because it takes a lot more than one minute to answer. Perhaps Senator Carr will do me the justice of asking me a question later so that I can give you another bout on it. The vice‐chancellors want to protect the money they are getting; anyone who gets money from the Commonwealth does want to do so. But I tell you this: they would much rather have the package we have than go along, steady as she goes. They want to be able to sell places to Australian students. They think it is unfair that international students can buy a place and Australians cannot.

ANSWER.PARA: The vice‐chancellors, generally speaking, agree that a higher HECS contribution is fair enough. After all, we do not give the kids who do not get to go to university $20,000 worth or something to set them up for the rest of their lives. The vice‐chancellors agree that we should return the HECS contribution from overloaded students, which you never did. Your government was very greedy. You kept that contribution to yourself, put it straight into the coffers. We are not doing that. Universities, I think, recognise the value in this package. You do not want to take too much notice of political posturing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in question time, I seek leave to make a statement and to provide some documents to the Senate.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: FAULKNER

TALK.START.PARA: —On the issue of leave to Senator Vanstone, it is the opposition's intention to grant leave. I have indicated to Senator Hill that the Leader of the Opposition will be seeking leave to make a response to the statement, which he has indicated will be agreed by the government.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I want to make a short statement on the circumstances surrounding the Wright family. This matter has generated considerable interest. I therefore wish to table documents in relation to this matter in order to ensure that the parliament is fully informed. A mistake was made. I believe it was an inadvertent one.
—You knew in advance. Why were the questions asked at estimates?

—I acknowledge that interjection and you will have the opportunity to correct it. It was an inadvertent mistake. It has been frankly acknowledged by me and by my department. There is nothing to hide; nor, by the way, did I ever seek to interest the media in the so‐called Wright family. Following media coverage, I simply responded to a limited number of media requests.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I provide the paper already made available to the Senate committee which was provided by the department and which sets out the profile of the Wright family. Second, I provide the profiles of actual families also given to me by the department which confirm the importance of the actual means test in ensuring that Austudy goes to those who are genuinely needy, not those who have had the opportunity to structure their financial affairs so as to gain the benefit despite being well off. That is why the Labor Party introduced the actual means test: so money would go to the needy and not the greedy, as Senator Newman said. That was the essence of the policy point which the department was seeking to make to me in developing the Wright example.

Third, I provide the note from the secretary of the department to me by which I was first advised that the Wrights were not an actual family, along with attachments to that letter. This note also frankly acknowledges errors made in the calculation of benefits. I just wish to add there that there may be some confusion on some senators' part. Senator Newman contacted me about the calculation of social security benefits. It is this document that I am tabling which first advised me that the Wright family was not an actual family.

Fourth, after discussion between my office and the secretary, minor amendments were made to the attachments. I enclose a copy of those attachments lest anybody think there is anything sinister in the minor amendments that were made.

BREAK.PARA: Fifth, I provide a chronology of events, including the subsequent consideration by me and my office of the secretary's note and of a letter to Senator Tierney as chair of the Senate committee. This chronology demonstrates that the matter was considered and acted upon in good time and that there was never any intention on my part, or that of my department, to sweep the error under the rug. I simply wanted to be very sure that I had correct and adequate information which would allow me to inform the committee in an accurate way, given the earlier error that had clearly occurred.

Sixth, I referred yesterday in this place to adjustments being made between the Wright case and the actual case from which it was drawn—which is included in the examples mentioned earlier as the second document I am tabling. In referring to that, I mentioned changes to family composition. Early last evening, the department faxed to me notice of some changes made to the business assets and education expenses of the so-called Wright family. I indicated during question time, I think, that I had received such advice last evening, and I include that advice.

Perhaps I should go back to that point. I indicate that I am providing to the Senate that which I am now advised is a complete account from the department of the changes made to what started off being an actual family.
Seventh, I provide—

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a Lego family, is it—a Barbie doll family?
—Are you going to be a scriptwriter for The Simpsons ?

—I really do not understand the humour, Madam President. I do not understand the humour for three reasons. Firstly, I have indicated a clear example of a minister being misled by his department in the past who did not take the opportunities to correct the record until he was caught out—unlike myself. For people with that former minister among their ranks to think it is funny and to somehow think that there should be some difference here amazes me. The second reason I cannot understand the humour is that, to the best of my knowledge, all of the public servants involved in this matter are public servants who served the previous government well—
—Oh!
—They are good public servants.
—He is an excellent public servant. Absolutely. He deserves better than you.
—Order!
—Senator Ray interjects, I think referring to Mr Hollway, that he is an excellent public servant, and I agree with that.
—Absolutely, and he deserves better than you.

—Senator Ray uncharitably says that he deserves better than me. Nonetheless, the department that served the previous government—I presume as well as they are serving us—acknowledges that they made a mistake and for you to laugh at them I do not think is so funny. The third aspect that I do not think is amusing, but which the opposition seems to think is amusing, is that the matter of correcting the record and taking the appropriate steps and acting with honesty and integrity is an important one; it is not a funny one. So I do not understand the humour.

BREAK.PARA: I understand some of the concerns here because with Labor ministers, when a mistake has been made, you have to drag it out of them. It was like getting teeth out of a chicken, as rare as hen's teeth, in respect of people from the other side who came in and did what they could to make the record as clear as possible. So I understand their embarrassment.

Nonetheless, seventhly I provide to the Senate the text of a letter sent to Senator Tierney by the secretary of my department reiterating that the department was in error in how the Wright case was characterised to me, summarising the context and apologising for the mistake.

Eighth, I provide a letter to me from the Clerk of the Senate, Harry Evans, in which he concludes that on the basis of precedent, and that precedent is Senator Schacht, the Senate would not hold me liable for giving misleading evidence.

Ninth, the secretary's letter—which is not a document to be tabled—to Senator Tierney has indicated, as I have in the chamber to the senator, who is still here, that I have overseas commitments next week when the committee will meet, as does the departmental secretary. These are important matters to try to promote higher education for Australia overseas. Although specialist officers will be present, the relevant division head will be on leave.

I have spoken today to Senator Tierney and indicated the times that the secretary and I will be back. I have indicated when Ms Lovett will be back and indicated that either when the secretary and I are back, or a few days later when Ms Lovett is back as well, we would be only too happy to meet with the committee. Despite putting all of this on the record, if they nonetheless have more questions I will be only too happy to meet at that time and tell them anything else we can.
Madam President, I am not sure whether I asked to table these documents. If I did not, I do so now, unless you do not want me to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Incorporate them in Hansard , then we can all read them.
—I seek leave to incorporate the documents in Hansard .

The purpose of this note is to:
. inform you that the Wright family is not an actual family by another name but a construct based on a real family with some variations;
. acknowledge that the Department has failed to make this clear to you before;
. inform you that DSS has advised us that some aspects of the calculations of payments to the Wrights are incorrect;
. suggest action that should now be taken in light of the impression left with the ERC and the Senate Estimates Committee, and picked up in press reporting, that the Wrights are an actual family.

This became clear to me only yesterday evening when we were considering a request from DSS to release data to them so that they could check the Social Security payments reportedly being made to the Wrights. Notwithstanding this, as Secretary, I must not only apologise on behalf of the Department but accept responsibility for our not accurately informing you of the status of the Wright case.
The substantive point remains that there are families well off but with a low taxable income and low net assets able to draw Government benefits in the absence of a rigorous actual means test.
It also remains true that the Government has correctly identified this problem and signalled its intention to address it.

To a significant extent the paper prepared in the Department on the Wright case properly illustrates these points. The problem is less its content than our fault in not clearly advising you on its status.

The paper (attached) notes that the family profile and financial circumstances are "based on a real family" tested by the Austudy Actual Means Test. This is correct. But some details (e.g. number of children) were adjusted to illustrate the range of payments that might be available to a family. The paper lists "benefits available" rather than benefits actually being paid.
The paper incorporated in Hansard in the course of the Estimates Hearings therefore contains these caveats.

However, I believe the Committee would have been left with the impression from the oral testimony that the Wrights were an actual family. I am seeking to check Hansard as urgently as possible, but certainly you said that you understood it was "a specific example". You were entitled to say this on the basis of the Department's advice to you.

Recommendation: that you write to the Chairman of the Senate Estimates Committee indicating that you have just been informed of the status of the Wright case and drawing this to the Committee's attention. A draft letter for your consideration is attached.

My recollection of the ERC discussions is that your Ministerial colleagues are also likely to have gained the impression that the Wrights are an actual family. Again, this is notwithstanding that a close reading of the document itself shows that the Wrights are based on a real family.
Recommendation: that you inform your colleagues on the ERC, perhaps through your office speaking to theirs and passing them a copy of the letter referred to above.

The calculations of Social Security benefits were not developed by the Department in consultation with DSS. That Department, having now had the opportunity to check the calculations, has advised us that the calculation made for Parenting Allowance ($5,954 p.a.) should be $156 p.a. There are two other small variations. A note from DSS is attached.
Recommendation: these discrepancies should also be drawn to attention in the letter to the Estimates Committee and the advice to ERC colleagues above.

Finally, there is the issue that a number of press reports have clearly taken the Wrights to be an actual family and the payments to them actual payments rather than benefits available. I believe this needs to be promptly corrected.
Recommendation: that you issue a media release, draft attached.

It is important to proceed in concert with Social Security in the handling of this matter. I have shown these papers to the Secretary of DSS, who has cleared them from his point of view, but coordination at Ministerial level is also important.
Recommendation: that before taking the steps proposed above you speak directly to Minister Newman.

Finally, I should note that the other cases which the Department put forward in the documents for the ERC were cases of actual families. Also, they did not include an attempt by the Department to calculate Social Security benefits. We can be confident, therefore, of their accuracy based on information actually provided to us by the clients.

BREAK.PARA: Differences Between the "Wright" Family and the Actual Family
The Wright family is based on an actual family who applied for AUSTUDY this year and were tested under the Actual Means Test and assessed as ineligible for AUSTUDY benefits.
Family Profile

The ages and the number of children were changed for the Wright family to illustrate the range of benefits that might be available. Ages of the four children in the actual family were 21, 20, 13 and 11. Ages of the three children in the Wright family were 16, 14 and 6 months. Therefore the real family had two children applying for AUSTUDY but in the Wright family only one child would be eligible to apply for AUSTUDY.
Education Expenses

The actual family declared $7,700 worth of education expenses which appeared to be understated as no expenditure was declared for the two younger students. The Wright family had $18,200 worth of education expenses for two secondary students attending private schools. However the total actual means of both families was the same at $188,969.
Taxable Income

Both the actual family and the Wright family had a combined parental taxable income of $12,323. The split of taxable income for the Wright family was 65% to the father and 35% to the mother which differed from the split in the actual family. The split was changed to illustrate the range of benefits that might be available to a mother with such a low taxable income.
Financial Profile

The actual family declared "Nil" business assets. Therefore the total assets declared by the actual family comprised only $50,000 of personal assets. This was unrealistic and not typical of a family tested under the Actual Means Test and so $120,000 worth of business assets were added to the Wright family's financial profile. The total assets for the Wright family were $170,000 worth of assets comprising $120,000 business assets and $50,000 personal assets.

$107,098 expenditure incurred by both the actual family and the Wright family comprises $19,552 expenditure on the principle family home and $87,546 on other investments/rental properties. These were the amounts declared by the actual family on their AUSTUDY forms.
The actual family and the Wright family had investment properties worth $500,000 but these were differently described. The real family has a terrace house and the Wright family has a city apartment.

Dear Senator Tierney

I am writing to you direct on the matter of the "Wright family" because the fault clearly lies with the Department. It was an incorrect characterisation of the case by the Department to the Minister which led Senator Vanstone in him to describe the Wright family as a specific example in the hearings of the Committee on 23 September 1996.

I myself wrongly believed the Wrights to be an actual case and, like the Minister, only became aware this was not so after the Committee hearings. Nonetheless, as Departmental Head, I accept responsibility for the mistake.

In brief, the Department provided the Minister earlier in the year with a number of actual examples of families well off but who, in the absence of the Actual Means Test, were able to draw AUSTUDY benefits.

The Wright family case was also put forward as a realistic demonstration, in the Department's view, of other benefits that could be obtained by a family with certain characteristics in the absence of a rigorous actual means test along the lines of that applied to AUSTUDY.

It was, as the relevant document prepared by the Department and tabled in the Committee says, based on a real family. But certainly variations were made, not with the intention to fabricate or mislead but to demonstrate the policy point the Department was seeking to make in its advice to the Minister.

Following the Committee hearings, the Department of Social Security on 25 September sought details of the Wrights in order to check the Social Security payments reportedly being made to them. In handling this request, it became clear to me then that the Wrights were not an actual case and also that in some respects the Department's calculations of benefits were in error.

I wrote to the Minister on 26 September to inform her both of the status of the Wrights and the errors in calculations. I conveyed my apologies to her. There was subsequent discussion with the Minister and her office in the normal way. Slight adjustments were made to the letter to be sent to you. The Minister's office then checked with their clerk, who suggested a sentence be inserted to ensure the letter was circulated to the members of the Committee. The Minister then wrote to you on 9 October advising the Committee of the correct situation.

I also felt it appropriate to write to you direct since both I and the Minister have overseas commitments next week when the Committee will meet and, although specialist officers will of course be present, the relevant Division Head will be on leave. The Minister has, however, informed me that she will be proposing to the Committee that if it wishes to meet to discuss this matter with her on return, then she would be happy to do so.
I wish to add my apologies personally and on behalf of the Department to the apology which Senator Vanstone made in her letter of 9 October and in the Senate yesterday.
I am copying this letter to the Minister.
Yours sincerely

Dear Minister
Evidence to Estimates Hearing

You have asked for advice on whether you could be held liable for giving misleading evidence to the Employment, Education and Training Legislation Committee in relation to the case of the "Wright family".

You wrote to the Committee on 9 October 1996 pointing out that the Committee is likely to have had the understanding, as you did, that the "Wright family" is an actual family, and indicated that you had been informed by the Department that a profile of a family had been developed by making adjustments to an actual case.

In past cases the Senate Privileges Committee had made it clear that leaving a committee with an incorrect impression as to the facts can be the equivalent of giving misleading evidence. The Committee has also made it clear, however, that a Minister is not guilty of contempt if the minister passes on incorrect information but corrects it when the error is discovered. This was the situation in the diesel fuel tax case, reported by the Committee in its 46th Report in 1994. A minister had passed on at an estimates hearing incorrect information about a proposed tax, but subsequently corrected the information in the Senate and before the Committee, although his first correction was in itself incomplete. The Committee found that false information was given, but the minister was not aware at the relevant time that the information was correct, and no contempt was committed. The Senate endorsed the findings of the Committee.
On this precedent, the Senate would not hold you liable for giving misleading evidence.
Please let me know if I can be of any further assistance.
Yours sincerely,
Harry Evans

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time on Thursday 10 October, Senator Lees asked me a question concerning the eligibility for diesel fuel rebate of the diesel which leaked from storage tanks at the manganese mine on Groote Eylandt, operated by the BHP subsidiary GEMCO. I seek leave to incorporate my answer in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
Senator the Hon Warwick Parer
Minister for Resources and Energy

During Question Time on Thursday 10 October Senator Lees asked me a question concerning the eligibility for diesel fuel rebate of the diesel which leaked from storage tanks at the manganese mine on Groote Eylandt, operated by the BHP Subsidiary GEMCO.

I am advised this leak was first confirmed in February 1995. It is not known when it commenced, but apparently well before that date. A drilling program carried out by the company to both identify the extent of the leakage and to enable recovery of the spilled fuel has indicated that of the order of 3 million litres escaped.

I have to say that I find it difficult to understand how a company can lose 3 million litres of diesel without noticing. GEMCO was fined $45,000 by the North Territory Government in March 1996 after pleading guilty to a charge of unlawfully permitting diesel fuel to enter the groundwater. Around 600,000 litres has so far been recovered by the use of skimmer pumps. That diesel is being cleaned and re-used for activities which would be eligible for the diesel fuel rebate. The company has advised me, however, that it does not intend to claim the rebate, for reasons which I will go into in a moment.
One of the many administrative issues we have had to deal with since coming to Government is the administration of the diesel fuel rebate scheme by the previous Government.

Significant deficiencies were identified by the Australian National Audit Office as long ago as May 1991. Over the following three years, the Labor administration established three separate interdepartmental committees and an Industry Commission Inquiry. The only response by the then Government was to legislate to reduce eligibility and to attempt to charge industry an administration fee, or perhaps in this case a mal-administration fee.
In 1993-94 a major fraud of approximately $1.4 million was discovered, which resulted in Customs commissioning consultants to review the rebate database system and its claims processing practices.
It is instructive to consider the comments of the Australian National Audit Office on this process, and I quote:
"The contract did not stipulate that a written report be provided and Customs did not modify its procedures for DFRS claims processing following completion of the $60,000 consultancy"
The administration of this scheme by the previous Government was a saga of inaction and incompetence.

I am advised that it is not possible to determine whether all or part of the diesel lost was, or was not, subject to a rebate claim without an extensive search of both Customs and GEMCO's records, even then, a conclusive outcome may not result.

I am further advised by the Australian Customs Service that under the existing legislation, payment of rebate is based on intended use for eligible activities. Recovery is possible where fuel is used for other than eligible purposes.
Any prospect that the rebate is not recoverable is not tolerable and will not be tolerated by this Government. It is yet another testimony to the incompetence of the previous Government.

Minister Prosser initiated a review of the administration of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme shortly after taking responsibility for the portfolio. That review was assisted by the efficiency audit of the scheme which we tabled on 2 May of this year. Senators will also be aware that the Government announced in the Budget that it will introduce legislation, with effect from 1 January 1997, to tighten eligibility for mining industry rebated under the scheme and to ensure that only legitimate claimants receive the rebate.
As part of the review the Minister will ensure that clarity is in the Act to make it clear that rebate is only paid when there is an eligibility.
In the meantime, the company is acting responsibility in relation to the recovery and use of the spilt fuel and I have requested regular progress reports to ensure that his situation continues.
I thank Senator Lees for her question and look forward to her support when the legislation comes before the Senate.
Senator Warwick Parer
17 October 1996

TALK.START.PARA: —During question time, Senator Lees asked me a question on the conditions in regard to woodchip export licences. I have since received an answer from the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and I seek leave to incorporate that answer in Hansard .

QUESTION.PARA: Leave granted.
I am advised that the conditions imposed in woodchip export licences are determined by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy.
The Minister is currently reviewing the conditions contained in 1996 woodchip export licences to determine whether they are appropriate for future licences.
The Minister has not yet considered applications for transitional woodchip export licences for the period from 1997 to 1999.
Senator Lees would be aware that it is the States which are responsible for timber harvesting, not the Commonwealth. Export licences do not give a right to harvest.

One of the conditions which will be included in all new licences is that exporters comply with all Commonwealth, State and Local Government laws, including those protecting environment and heritage values.

I wish to emphasise how important it is for the Government to progress implementation of Regional Forest Agreements because it is under these agreements that we will achieve the nationally agreed aim of establishing a comprehensive, adequate and representative (CAR) forest reserve system in this country.

Minister Anderson has advised me that any licence conditions will be consistent with the regional forest agreement process and agreements with the States made under this process, such as Deferred Forest Agreements, which give interim protection to high conservation values forests which may be needed for the reserve system.

The Minister is particularly aware of the regard Australians have for rainforest values, and will ensure as far as possible that appropriate protections are afforded to those values, consistent with the National Forest Policy Statement.
Regional Forest Agreements are a far more appropriate instrument for addressing environment protection issues.
Licences issued by the former Labor Minister for Resources, under which exports currently take place from Tasmania, allow the export of woodchips derived from rainforest species.

The areas agreed by the former Labor Government as being available for harvesting in Tasmania include some rainforest species. These areas of forest are critical to the operations of the Tasmanian veneer industry.

The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has advised me that the woodchip export licences he issued last week under the new category for sawmill residues and silvicultural thinnings do not prohibit the export of woodchips derived from agricultural clearing, so long as that clearing has taken place in accordance with State and local controls.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Health Policy for the Veteran Community in Rural and Remote Areas

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woods, Sen Bob

TALKER.NAME: Senator WOODS
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) relating to health policy for the veteran community in rural and remote areas, to incorporate the statement in Hansard and to take note of the statement and a related document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows—
Madam President, it is my privilege to introduce a special policy for Australia's veterans‐ a Health Policy for the Veteran Community in Rural and Remote Areas .
Coming from an electorate in Queensland—around three times the size of Victoria, I know only too well that services in rural and remote Australia are often missing or many miles away.
The motivation for developing this policy stems from this Government's election commitment to ensure the needs of people in rural and remote Australia are not forgotten.
Unfortunately often what makes good policy sense in a metropolitan context is impractical and unworkable in the country. Government must take account of this fact and frame policy accordingly.
This is what the people of Australia who elected us, especially those in rural and remote areas, expect us to do.
This policy is a downpayment on the Coalition Government's commitment to meet the requirements of veterans living in rural and remote areas.

Of the 337,000 veterans, war widows and dependants currently entitled to health care through my Department, over 31 per cent live outside the major metropolitan areas. It is in areas with smaller populations and the remote locations where the problems are greatest. They often have none of the services the rest of us take for granted.
In addition, although health care services may be lacking close to home, veterans may have considerable difficulty in travelling to the larger centres to receive appropriate care.

The majority of veterans are now aged over 70 years. This ageing is creating further demand for a wider range of health care and support services. The veteran community also includes many younger veterans who served in Korea, Malaya, Vietnam and in more recent engagements including UN peacekeeping missions. Their needs and those of carers and indigenous veterans are quite different to those of older veterans.

This Government is committed to honouring the debt of gratitude owed to those who fought for today's freedom. Rural Australia was a great source of recruitment. It is an important goal of this Government to ensure equity of access and entitlement to all veterans regardless of where they live.
This Health Policy for the Veteran Community in Rural and Remote Areas goes a great distance in achieving this goal. It sets out
the broad strategic directions and strategies to build on and enhance programs to target services better;
it outlines initiatives to specifically addresses service gaps, and
it builds in better feedback and planning mechanisms to meet the needs of the veteran community.

In short, this policy spells out what we can do to make health care services easier to get to, to promote awareness of preventive care measures and to improve our communications with the veteran community and health care providers.

The policy looks to the total health service delivery framework including Commonwealth and State governments, private and community‐based organisations, and looks to capitalise on opportunities for joint arrangements with them.

This policy is about what is achievable and realistic. It comes up with practical solutions that we can implement now within budget constraints. It flags what we can do in future to enhance provision of health care for rural and remote veterans. It is, however, just the first stage.

Underpinning the development of this policy are wide ranging consultations with veterans, war widows, doctors, nurses, other health and community care providers, carers, ex‐service organisations and others in Rockhampton, Thursday Island, Roma, Alice Springs, Bunbury, Geraldton, Cobar, Bourke and Echuca.

Consultations made clear that, veterans living in rural and remote areas cannot and generally do not expect to have the same level and range of locally available health care services as people who live in cities. The policy acknowledges this reality, but, through better focusing and targeting of programs and services, I believe the veteran community can still expect the best possible deal.

Outlined in this policy are national, state and local initiatives, many of which are pilots, testing innovative approaches to service delivery and information provision. These have the potential to become the basis of practical, cost‐effective on‐the‐ground solutions right across the country.
I would now like to highlight a few examples of some of the initiatives.
The veteran community told us that access to health care and support services is an issue of concern.
At a national level my Department will:
. Establish joint arrangements with State Government Health Departments and individual providers to extend visiting specialist schemes, and increase visits by allied health professionals.
. Extend provision of medical services through the Royal Flying Doctor Service (RFDS) including:
‐ links between RFDS psychological services and the Vietnam Veterans' Counselling Services and
‐ providing Annual Health Care Plans by RFDS medical practitioners for veterans.
and at local and state levels:
. the Rural Medication Review Program in Bundaberg, Roma and Wagga Wagga to improve pharmaceutical use and reduce adverse drug reactions will be expanded and
we will extend the rural psychiatric service which currently operates in Dubbo to other areas in NSW.
Convenient and affordable transport is obviously important for access to services, especially if those services are not available locally.
Nationally, I have asked my Department to:
. Ensure that guidelines for long distance travel for treatment are administered to take account of personal needs, and
. Provide financial assistance to the accompanying person, where a veteran or war widow's medical condition requires him or her to be accompanied to travel for treatment.
At the local level:
. Community Care Seeding Grants will be used in Portland and Belmont in rural Victoria to evaluate trials of community transport models.
Health education and preventive care are important in improving veterans' and war widows' quality of life and reducing the need for more intensive health care.
Among the proposed national initiatives are:

. The development of national health promotion products including a video to assist in the early detection and management of prostate disease, materials to assist management of chronic health conditions such as dementia, arthritis and back care.
At state and local levels:
. Veterans' health promotion activities and Quality of Life Education programs will be arranged in rural areas;
. A pilot walking program will be developed in Burra, South Australia, for veterans and local school children, and
. Through the Telefriend Program, isolated or housebound veterans in South Australia will be encouraged to become more involved through links to other veterans across the state.
To improve the planning and delivery of my Department's services, we need to improve our knowledge of the local needs and circumstances of the veteran community in different rural and remote areas.
Our strategy is to extend the country visits and outreach programs and identify opportunities for joint arrangements such as one‐stop shops with other government and community organisations.
Specifically, we will:

. Conduct a program of teams made up of my Department's officers to consult with the local veteran community, health providers, community and government organisations. These teams will develop local strategies and provide information about the full range of the Department's services. For example during 1996 and 1997, these teams will visit Thursday Island, Bamaga, Miles, Cunnamulla, Alice Springs, Marrawah and Mallacoota.
. Additional Veterans Advice Network services will be established.
Another major issue to emerge was information or the lack thereof. Veterans and war widows are not always aware of their health care and support entitlements and nor are their health care providers.
To address these concerns, at the national level:
. An information package about entitlements and health services will be published.
. A rural section will be included in the Department's national newspaper for veterans, Vetaffairs, and
Locally:
. A pilot three‐day Veterans Information Expo will be conducted in Mackay.

Through the consultations we found that there are groups within the veteran community with special needs including Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander veterans, veterans with war‐related stress or mental health conditions, frail aged veterans and carers.

Many frail aged veterans and war widows suffer from chronic illness or high levels of disability and if unable to live independently they often are obliged to move to a hostel or nursing home a great distance from family and friends.
At a national level the Department will:

. Ensure an appropriate proportion of funds for the Residential Care Development Scheme, Community Care Seeding Grants Program and the Joint Venture Scheme are directed to their residential and community care needs,
and at the local level:

. A report will be prepared on the barriers and opportunities which may affect the veteran community in achieving equitable allocations of residential services in rural and remote areas of South Australia.

I am particularly concerned about the needs of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander veterans who made a significant contribution to the defence of Australia during World War Two. In the Torres Strait alone, we know that almost every male of enlistment age signed up.
Among other national initiatives, I have asked my Department to:

. In the first place identify them and then raise awareness among Aboriginal veterans of their entitlements through contact with and provision of information to Aboriginal organisations and communities.
For veterans in the Torres Strait, we will:
. improve access for veterans to Rehabilitation Appliance Program items, and
. financially support the Queensland Department of Health in establishing a podiatry service on Thursday Island to assist those veterans with chronic illnesses such as diabetes.

Veterans who suffer from dementia, war‐related stress and other mental health conditions very often have an especially difficult time in getting the services they need in rural and remote locations, where their conditions may be exacerbated by isolation.
Specifically the National Centre for War Related Post Traumatic Stress Disorder will be used to enhance care for veterans in rural and remote areas by
researching the care needs and effectiveness of PTSD treatment;
arranging continuing education seminars and workshops for providers, for example, in Tamworth and Armidale; and
further developing access arrangements to PTSD treatment programs including for veterans in the Swan Hill and Mildura.
Satellite PTSD programs will be introduced for the veteran community in country New South Wales.

Carers play a major role within the veteran community and require support and access to respite care. Many veterans and even some of the carers themselves, suffer from chronic illnesses and disabilities.
To help this group:
. A dementia training program for carers in the veteran community will be provided in 30 rural and remote centres,
and at the local level:

. the co‐ordination of respite service in the Grafton region in NSW will be improved to enable veterans, their carers and health professionals to call one number to access all residential and in‐home respite places in the region, and

Health care providers in rural communities play a critical role, and are often the major source of health service information for veterans. It is essential they are given the most appropriate support.

Providers are often not fully aware of Veterans' Affairs services and entitlements. My strategy is to assist them in giving the best possible quality care including better use of information technology. A recent survey of the Department's health care providers found nearly 70 per cent have an office computer and 17 per cent have access to the Internet. At a national level, my Department will:

. Provide information on the Department's Internet home page and through its publications to increase awareness of veterans' health issues and health care services. Guides will also be provided to other sources of information.

. Advise LMOs about elements of the Repatriation Comprehensive Care Scheme and Annual Health Care Plans for veterans and other changes to DVA arrangements through a Departmental news sheet to be faxed regularly.
Ex‐service organisations too, provide valuable support to the veteran community, including home and hospital visiting, pensions and advocacy advice and a range of aged care services.

Some rural sub‐branches of ex‐service organisations are now closing as membership declines and others are reporting increased pressure on their welfare officers to provide information and advice on health and aged care matters. Over recent years these organisations have been supported through grants programs. This support will be extended by:
. Increasing training provided to ex‐service organisation personnel under the Training Information Program in rural and remote areas, and
. Reviewing and amending guidelines for grants programs to ensure an appropriate focus on rural and remote areas.
Initiatives at the local level include:
. Supporting the development of new day clubs in the South Coast and Hunter Valley regions in New South Wales.

In terms of housing, many veterans and war widows told us that they want to live independently in their local communities for as long as possible. As veterans age, their housing needs change and their homes may need alterations, repairs or maintenance to enable them to continue to live independently.
In this area, my Department will:
. In conjunction with Westpac, examine better options for people living in rural and remote areas to take up their entitlement to Defence Service Home loans to enable modifications.
Locally:

. A project in the Goldfields region of Western Australia will be established in association with a community organisation, to provide regular telephone contact at times of special need, such as on discharge from hospital, for those living alone, and

. A project on home safety and security in the Wodonga area to provide veterans with an assessment of risks in their homes. Advice will be given on preventive action to reduce the likelihood of home accidents and to enhance veterans' ability to live independently.

Financial independence can have a major impact on veterans and war widows' general well‐being. Many are not fully aware of their entitlements and find the assessment process complex and difficult. I have asked my Department to investigate ways of improving this situation by looking at possibilities such as providing a single point of contact for veterans about these matters.

This policy shows how the government can expand its role in this area to better meet the needs of the veteran community . By focusing our attention and thinking about how solutions can meet local problems, we can do more.
In concluding, Madam President, I want to stress that the policy highlights what we know we can proceed with now and flags future plans. It represents the first phase of a long‐term strategy.

I want to take this opportunity to thank my parliamentary colleagues Trish Worth, Kay Elson, Mal Brough and Sharman Stone who so willingly became involved in the consultations with the veteran community and their health care providers in Western Australia, New South Wales and Victoria. I also want to thank the local members for areas as far flung as Thursday Island and Alice Springs.

Most of all, I want to express my warmest appreciation to the many veterans, war widows, doctors, nurses and other health care providers in the isolated regions of Australia who extended their hospitality to all those people involved in the consultations and who gave us such valuable insights.

This document is about finding ways to improve the lives of veterans and war widows who live in rural and remote Australia by giving them practical information, better access to health care services and innovative solutions to some specific problems.
Madam President, I commend this Health Policy for the Veteran Community in Rural and Remote Areas to the Senate

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the statement by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and a related document entitled Health policy for the veteran community in rural and remote areas , and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement and document.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to this motion, I would like to congratulate—as Mr Martin, our shadow minister in the other place, did yesterday—the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) for this document entitled Health policy for the veteran community in rural and remote areas . While it is a very glossy document, it also mentioned some very good things. A lot of hard work has gone into the formulation of this document both by members of the lower house and by the Department of Veterans' Affairs, which has a staff of very dedicated and caring people to look out for the needs of the veteran community.

BREAK.PARA: This is an area where, as much as we can, we should take a bipartisan approach to the formulation of policy and the enaction of that policy, because this is a group of people who have made a significant contribution to this country. For those who are actual veterans, they have laid their lives on the line; for those who are the widows or widowers of deceased veterans, they have had to live with and care for someone whose life has probably been shortened by their military service. I think it is very important that we continue to recognise the contribution that has been made by them.

The veteran community is an ageing community. The bulk of the veterans now are Second World War veterans, but the Korean and Vietnam veterans are also, unfortunately, ageing. As someone who was a contemporary of the Vietnam veterans, it is coming up to 25 years next year since the last lot of our troops were brought out of Vietnam. It does not seem that long ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are getting old.
—We are getting old. Of course, if we are getting old, it means that those people who are our peers are also getting old.

BREAK.PARA: This document has identified very clearly the rural and remote areas of Australia where the population of veterans are located. This is a very important issue for the department in its delivery of services. There are 337,000 people currently entitled to health care through the Department of Veterans' Affairs, and 31.6 per cent of those people live outside the metropolitan area.

When you look at the statistics of where the rest of the community live in Australia, the veteran community is different in composition in its patterns of living. Most Australians in this country live in metropolitan areas on the eastern seaboard, but a lot of veterans have chosen to move to or to stay in the country areas. That may reflect their age, because a lot of them are older and have gone back to those areas. It may also reflect some of the soldier settlement schemes that were put in place after the war ended. But it does provide the department with a challenge to meet in its provision of health services.

In this document, the minister has brought together all of the processes that the department is involved in, which is a very good thing. It looks at the one-stop shops to bring all the services together and it looks at a number of projects that are going to be piloted, which I think is an ideal way for the department to proceed. Many of us will view with great interest the outcome of these pilot programs.

The area of transport, particularly now with the Second World War veterans becoming quite elderly, is becoming more of an issue. The veterans will all be very close to the age of 70 or over—just doing some quick mental arithmetic—and many are approaching the age of 80. I know that, with my own parents who are aged 75 and nearly 80, transport is becoming an issue for them living in a rural community. If they require treatment or assessment in a centre in Sydney, which has happened, they are no longer able to drive themselves there. There are dependent upon my brother to do the driving and to provide the transport for them. However, there are many veterans who live in smaller communities that do not have that family support there for the provision of transport. This document is calling for more flexibility within the repatriation transport arrangements.

The veterans have asked that their support needs be taken into account when they travel to metropolitan centres for extended periods of treatment. Often the veterans will need somebody to accompany them on these visits. These issues are highlighted in the national and state and local initiatives outlined in this statement. One of the initiatives is to use the community care seeding grants program in Belmont to evaluate trials of two community transport models to assess their suitability for general application in rural Victoria. That is the standard of programs proposed to be undertaken as pilots. That is a very good thing.

PARA.BREAK: This statement outlines that the department is prepared to look at the guidelines under which the programs are administered and ensure that they take into account the needs of these rural and remote veterans in terms of the access and administration of these ser vices. The department is also prepared to provide some financial assistance to the accompanying person, in cases where a veteran or war widow's—and I suggested it should be widowers as more women who have served die and their spouses require assistance—medical condition requires him or her to be accompanied to travel for treatment and while the veterans is admitted for treatment in a centre away from their area. It is the very humane programs and plans that are being put in place that attract my attention and highlight to many people the very valuable results that will arise out of this policy statement. I think the minister is to be congratulated on this policy statement.

BREAK.PARA: Many pilot programs are going to be conducted. I wish all of those involved in them well. This is a good statement which outlines the direction that needs to be taken, the need for one‐stop shops and the needs of people living in rural and remote areas. The statement also looks at the need for counselling for Vietnam veterans which is very important. It also recognises the effect of post‐traumatic stress disorder and post‐traumatic stress syndrome which, for many years, was ignored. We did not want to accept that some veterans suffered some sort of trauma and stress following their service and the horrific situations they faced. This statement recognises that there is a need for post‐traumatic stress counselling and support and that is to be commended.

There is also a recognition in the statement that many Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders made a significant contribution to the defence of Australia during World War II. These gentleman are very elderly and many live in small and isolated communities in the north and north west of this country. They are probably not aware of their entitlements, under the Department of Veterans' Affairs Act, to support, medical care and attention.

This statement is specifically designed to raise awareness among Aboriginal veterans of their entitlements through contact with, and provision of information to, Aboriginal organisations and communities. Training will also be provided to Department of Veterans' Affairs staff in consultation with ATSIC to enhance awareness of culturally appropriate services to meet the needs of indigenous veterans. For many years indigenous veterans have talked about the maltreatment and discrimination they received after they were discharged from the armed forces. I think this goes some little way towards redressing the traumas and discrimination they suffered and to make sure that they are able to have what is rightfully theirs.

I note with caution that there is no new funding announced for these policies. They are to be funded from the recurrent DVA budget which has been subject to an across the board two per cent reduction in running costs. That amounts to about $20 million over four years. Administrative efficiency savings of $48.5 million over four years must be absorbed by the department. This is the code for the slashing of spending. I desperately hope that this slashing of spending is not going to impact adversely on the programs that are being outlined. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee, Sen Bill

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Scott) should be congratulated on this statement. I think it is important to note that changing demographics in Australia over the last 10 or 15 years have meant that many of our veterans who may have lived and worked in city areas have moved to areas outside capital cities. That is why it is important that the government has done what it has done, which is to make the statement and make it very clear the way in which it intends to deal with the issue of veterans who live in regional and country Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I will give senators some examples of the sorts of problems that we are facing in terms of delivering services to veterans. Look for example at the state of Queensland. Senator Hogg would be aware of the number of retirees from both Brisbane and interstate who have moved to the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast, Hervey Bay or Cairns and the difficulty in providing services to them, be they medical or other services. That is why what the government has done is very important and why we need to focus on getting some real outcomes.

BREAK.PARA: One of the problems we had with the previous government was that they made a lot of noise about looking after veterans but when it came to delivering services, particularly to veterans outside the capital city areas, it did not happen. One of the consequences of having a Minister for Veterans' Affairs such as Minister Scott who lives outside a capital city is that he is acutely aware of the problems that are being experienced. I think Mr Scott deserves the congratulations of both sides for what he has done. I seek leave to continue my remarks.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 15 October, on motion by Senator Cooney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a privilege to stand here today and speak to this document, although I must say at the outset of my contribution that I do have great concerns about the case that was used to establish reasons why the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission ought to make significant recommendations to the government about the removal of any form of age discrimination from the Public Service Act 1922.

SPEECH.PARA: My concerns were brought about by the fact that the complaints, which culminated in this report to the parliament, were made by four airline pilots who were compulsorily retired from their positions as airline pilots because they had reached the age of 60 years. If there is an occupation in this country which should have extremely high standards of safety applying to it, perhaps even age limits, I think the occupation of airline pilots might be the one that we should remove last from the list of occupations that have age barriers and age limits attached to them.

It is an extremely stressful occupation. Many senators in this place would have sat in the cockpit in light aircraft. I suggest that all of us, from time to time—as I have done recently on a Qantas flight—sit up the front with the pilots when they are coming in to land at one of our major airports. One gets the real, distinct feeling of pressure that is applied to those individuals who have the responsibility not only for the lives of persons on board but also for many of the people on the ground and areas surrounding the airports where pilots land their aircraft.

For many years there have been arbitrary and, in some cases, very unreal age limits applying to people. It certainly used to apply in the Defence Force. It applies in our police forces. As I understand it, in my state of Western Australia, senior police officers have to retire when they reach the age of 55. Age limits used to apply in politics. I can recall some very vigorous debates in my party back in Western Australia involving those of us who were advocating that there ought be age limits—it was a good way of removing people from the political positions they occupied!

It is interesting that, after growing up in the political party I grew up in, I actually came to witness people who, having argued vigorously for the imposition of age limits at one point in time, somewhat later in their careers arguing for completely the opposite. I am not in any way implying that their latter arguments were influenced by the fact that they too had aged. Might I quickly add that I have made it public that age limits will not affect me in the next round of preselections, because there will not be a next round of preselections for me. But I am going to be round this place for a quite a period of time.

The report itself is an interesting one and not one, I suggest, that the government should immediately accept without qualification, without exceptions. There are still areas in this society where age limits ought apply—that is, age limits at the beginning of a working life and at the end of a working life. I do not think we ought to automatically abolish all age barriers that are in place in our society.

I put on the record that I chaired the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act, which made a very quick recommendation very early in its inquiry that the age limits applying to judges of the Family Court ought to be lifted from the age of 65 to 70 to at least bring them into line with all other judges in the Commonwealth jurisdiction. I accept in general what the human rights commission has to say in this report, but we have to look individually and specifically at where it applies within the Public Service Act.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney, Sen Barney

TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with much of what Senator McKiernan said, but I must confess that what he said at the start of his speech brought to me considerable shock. He was suggesting that somebody aged 60 was not fit to fly an aeroplane. For a person whom I have had great respect for over the years to have this unnatural—I use the word advisedly—prejudice against people just because they are 60 comes as a shock.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Chris Sidoti is saying that age should not by itself be a bar to what a person can do and to his or her place in the work force, in the same way that gender or disability or race should not be a bar. If a person who is 60 is unwell, is not physically or mentally fit to fly, then he or she should not be allowed to fly. If a person who is of a particular sex is not properly qualified to carry on a particular job, then he or she should not be given it. But Mr Sidoti points out here that a specific factor should not by itself be a means of stopping people from doing what they want.

I think Senator McKiernan is being particularly selfish in saying that he is not going to stand for preselection again. He is a senator who has performed wonders in this chamber over many years. I see Senator Crane and Senator Eggleston over there, other great Western Australians. I think they would agree with me when I say that none of them should retire from this place. Senator McKiernan, in particular, should reconsider what he has told us here today. I think he would bring joy to many a heart in Australia if he changed his mind.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
